story: Created with Sketch.In most&nbspprofessions,&nbspwomen of a certain age are invisible. But there is one area where the older woman is&nbspthriving.&nbspIn the week that Madonna turns 60, David Lister applauds the 60-something females who are gliding into pensionable age, with fan bases, voices, charisma and sexiness intactClick to followThe Independent OnlinePatti Smith, edgy and androgynous and still pulling in the crowds, performs at the Roundhouse at a Palestine charity eventIt’s a truism that older women have had their visibility problems. City boardrooms are short of women in general, and women over 60 are certainly thin on the ground. Most notably, broadcasting has been notoriously shy of giving older women screen time.It was less than&nbsptwo years ago that the head of the regulator&nbspOfcom&nbspaccused the BBC of “not doing as good a job as it should be” in its treatment of older women, after many complaints from viewers about a lack of mature female presenters.The corporation had long faced criticism for its treatment of older women, and lost an age discrimination case brought by Countryfile presenter Miriam O’Reilly, who was sacked in 2009, to make way for younger presenters. &nbspBut there is one area where the older woman is suddenly and somewhat unexpectedly thriving – rock music. Madonna celebrates her 60th birthday on Saturday. Kate Bush has just celebrated hers. In fact, they are the spring chickens. Suzi Quatro, 68, and Patti Smith, 71, are not just still rocking, they are still snarling. Cher at 72 pops up with a delightful cameo in the Mamma Mia!&nbspmovie. The queen of soul, Aretha Franklin, is still recording at 76.&nbspWho’d have thought it? Look back to the 1960s and there were precious few women at all in pop music, let alone older ones. In the UK, Sandie Shaw, Dusty Springfield, Marianne Faithfull and a handful of others carried the fight to the mass of male groups (the word boyband had yet to be invented).No one thought then about whether the stars would still be recording and performing in old age. Indeed the concept was unthinkable – for men as well as women, for stars as well as fans. When I put it to Paul McCartney that he must be surprised to be still going, he replied: “I do rub my eyes. I didn’t foresee it. In The Beatles we always said 10 years. But it kept on and kept on and it kept being good and we seemed to be the people who could do it. Now there is a great young generation of people who can also do it, but it tends to be that the people packing them in are the people who have the material, have hits, songs people know, and I think that’s important. I think they have stagecraft, they have an ability with an audience.”There’s no doubting that the likes of Madonna and Kate Bush have stagecraft in spades. Even in an industry that ostensibly prizes youthfulness and a certain amount of athleticism on stage, the female superstars, like the male, are now gliding into pensionable age, with fan bases, voices, charisma and downright sexiness still intact.&nbspThough, when it comes to longevity, the women themselves didn’t always think it would be the case. Joni Mitchell once remarked, all too despondently: “Record companies want the look. And if you’re over 50, however well preserved, you just don’t have the look.”Maybe the look, or audience perception of the look, has changed. No one remotely cared that Kate Bush looked older than they remembered her (quelle surprise) when she made her stage comeback after 35 years in 2014. And tickets were inevitably like gold dust. I was there to note that she sounded the same, and she still exuded charisma and stage presence.She did a staggering run of 22 performances. Two things perhaps attested to the more mature Kate. The show was only part rock concert, it was also part theatre with video and dance, and even the odd comedy sketch starring her son. Also, she gave all her audiences an instruction on her website, which bore witness to the fact that she comes from an earlier generation than today’s performers. She wrote: “I very much want to have contact with you as an audience, not with iPhones, iPads or cameras.”Suzi, 68,&nbspsays she'll 'retire when I go on stage, shake my ass and there is&nbspsilence' (Getty)&nbspEarlier this year I witnessed the return to live performance of Annie Lennox, at the age of 63. To raise funds for her charity she did a one-off show which was largely a chat show, interspersed with the odd song at the piano, going through her life and career. The self-deprecating humour was erting: “When I was studying at the Royal Academy of Music, I lived on £3 a week.” Pause. “Scottish people can do that.” Pause. “And we like it.”Perhaps she had stumbled across the format for the older star, a chat show setting interspersed with the odd song. Except, at the end that she knocked everyone there for six with a breathtaking 30 minute performance of Eurythmics and solo hits that showed she retained all her talent. She was the epitome of soul as she belted out Eurythmics anthems, sometimes crawling sensuously across the floor as she did so. The only surprise was that she had (lamentably) eschewed live performance for 10 years.For some female legends, the routine can be tiring. I was at Marianne Faithfull’s most recent London appearance, an intimate show at Ronnie Scott’s jazz club. Plagued by a variety of physical problems over the years, she had a walking stick and performed most of the show sitting down. It was nevertheless a beguiling evening. But notably at one point she actually pleaded with her fans to allow her to retire. “Please let me go,” she said, “I can’t go on for ever. I’m not Keith,” referring to her long-time friend Keith Richards of The Rolling Stones, definitely not one of life’s quitters.Madonna, too, is not one of life’s quitters. Her fitness routine keeps her more than show-ready, even for a show as heavy on breathless choreography as hers. But I think there is another clue to her longevity in what she said to the audience at one of her shows that I attended 15 years ago. Just before her final encore, she said in idiosyncratic style: “When I was a girl I always thought ‘grown-ups can f**k off’. But now I’m 45 years old, I have children of my own, and you know what, grown-ups can still f**k off!”As I say, it was a piece of philosophy delivered in her personal style. But it perhaps partly explains her longevity and continuing appeal. She retains the anarchic spirit she had when she burst on the scene. Female rock stars, just like their male counterparts, and possibly more so, have no intention of growing old gracefully. They haven’t just retained their vocal prowess and stage presence, they have retained the hint of adolescent rebelliousness that has always been an intrinsic part of rock’s appeal. And having met both Madonna and Suzi Quatro, I can attest that in both cases the aggressive, in yer face attitude is not just a stage technique.But rock-star rebelliousness is not the only reason that rock and pop’s biggest female stars go on and on or come back after long absences. Kate Bush was never keen on playing live and before her comeback had only done one tour of the country. But she was persuaded to perform again by her teenage son. As she had a song on one album about watching his clothes go round and round in the washing machine, it was clear that a request from him would, fortunately, carry weight.Victoria Beckham is, of course, far from the vintage of Bush, Madonna and the other older stars. But when the Spice Girls had their reunion tour, it’s interesting that she said the key reason she wanted to do it was that her children had seen Dad play football and knew all about his skills. Now was a chance for them “to see what Mummy did” before they were born.Performing for a global audience is important. But performing for the family clearly also is a factor in keeping the career going.Jonathan Morrish, a long-time senior executive at Sony record company, and now a music industry PR consultant, says: “Women generally live longer than men, so it should come as no surprise that so many as they get older seem to flourish creatively with their music and on stage. None of this is easy. I know from the many artists that I have worked with you need tenacity. So perhaps it’s the staying power they had to show at the beginning of their careers, perhaps a savvy emotional intelligence –&nbspwhatever it is, I admire and welcome it. And applaud them.”&nbspAnd even for those female rock and pop stars who have decided to call it a day, a new avenue has opened up: the stage musical. Right now in London, audiences can see Tina Turner on stage at one theatre, and The Supremes and all the other Motown stars at another. Or at least, one can enjoy their music and life stories, delivered by lookalikes and sound-alikes. It’s possible not just to go on into old age, but literally forever.Faithfull pleaded with a crowd at Ronnie Scotts: 'Please let me go. I&nbspcan’t go on for ever. I’m not Keith' (Alamy)Meanwhile, there is a core of&nbsp 60- and 70- something female rock stars, who thankfully show no signs of even thinking about stopping and relying on musicals to seal their immortality.No one puts it better than Suzi Quatro, celebrating 54 years in the business, who states: “I will retire when I go on stage, shake my ass and there is silence.”David Lister is the former arts editor of The IndependentEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Gazza had to leave the Sky Sports programme early after sleeping tablets left him slurring his speech and feeling unwellClick to followThe Independent OnlinePaul Gascoigne says sleeping tablets caused him to cut Soccer AM appearance shortPaul Gascoigne has blamed sleeping tablets for having to cut his appearance on live TV show Soccer AM short.The former Newcastle, Tottenham and England footballer appeared to slur his speech and had to leave the Sky Sports&nbspprogramme early on Saturday morning because he was feeling unwell.Host John Fendley explained Gascoigne, affectionately known as Gazza, had left the studio early about 45 minutes into the programme.“I just want to say Gazza was here earlier,” said Fendley.“Gazza’s not feeling wonderful and he’s not too great so he’s left us so we’ll catch up with you very soon Paul, all the very best mate.”Gazza's&nbsprepresentative revealed the England hero suffers from insomnia and took some sleeping tablets to get a good night's rest before his appearance.And Gazza himself later rubbished claims he was drunk, tweeting that he had taken some sleeping tablets the night before and was still feeling the effects during the show.Madejski Stadium on November 12, 2009, in Reading, England. (Christopher LeeGetty Images)“Ha just read some of the tweets some say I’m looking well others say it’s the best they’ve seen me and others are saying I was drunk it’s every time I’m doing well that’s ok I been taking sleeping tablets to try kip that all love GAZZA,” said the 51-year-old.Gazza has battled alcohol addiction for a number of years and has been in and out of rehab.He recently split from girlfriend Sara Lovett after just a few months, and asked the public to help him find a new girlfriend via Twitter.Spurs begin season with a win at Newcastle for second year in rowPoliticians urged to lift ban on boxing and martial arts in prisonPolice and CPS branded 'appalling' as tyre slasher case collapsesElon Musk and Tesla accused of fraud after 'going private' tweetsThe father-of-three, from Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, started his career at&nbspNewcastle United as a schoolboy, turning&nbspprofessional in 1985.He joined Tottenham Hotspur&nbspin 1988, also starring for Lazio,&nbspRangers,&nbspMiddlesbrough, Everton&nbspand Burnley throughout a career marked by sublime talent&nbspand a fondness for practical jokes.He made his England debut in 1988, going on to win 57 caps, score&nbsp10 goals&nbspand help&nbspthe team to the semi-finals of Italia '90 and Euro '96.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log in

story: Created with Sketch.Exclusive: Survey&nbspby BMG claims that every group under the age of 55 also wants the chance to decide the terms of Britain’s exit from the blocClick to followIndy PoliticsYoung voters want final say on Theresa May’s Brexit deal, poll finds Young voters want a final say on the Brexit deal with the European Union, an exclusive poll for The Independent has found.The new survey suggests support for a vote on the agreement eventually reached by Theresa May with negotiators in Brussels is strongest among 18- to 24-year-olds, with 55 per cent backing the idea.It comes after an analysis of census data showed that more than 1.4m young people would be eligible to vote in a fresh referendum compared with the Brexit vote in 2016, raising questions about the potential impact of this new cohort.MPs can legislate for fresh referendum within weeks, says CableBrexit: Half of Britons want final say in no-deal scenario, poll findsI want to leave the EU but I support a Final Say on the Brexit dealNorthern Irish students’ organisation calls for vote on Brexit dealAs a student leader, here’s why I’m backing a Final Say on BrexitThe Independent’s Final Say campaign – calling for a public vote on any deal reached – has so far received over 600,000 backers in a petition, with MPs from across the political ide throwing their weight behind it.The survey of 1,481 people by BMG claims every group under the age of 55 also wants the chance to decide the terms of Britain’s exit from the bloc – something the prime minister has categorically ruled out.Overall, when asked about the possibility of a referendum should a Brexit deal be reached between Britain and the EU, 48 per cent said they would support a public vote while 24 per cent would be opposed and 11 per cent said they did not know.The survey suggested that just one in seven voters (14 per cent) would back the prime minister’s Chequers plan for Britain’s withdrawal from the EU if given the chance at a referendum, while 27 per cent said they believed the UK should leave with no deal and 43 per cent would back remaining inside the bloc.It also found that if Ms May fails to secure a deal that her ministers can agree to later this year, nearly half (49 per cent) of respondents believed she should be replaced as prime minister.A majority – 52 per cent – said that if this scenario played out then a general election should be held with the Conservatives’ new leader. Just under a third (28 per cent) said she should be replaced without a vote while 20 per cent said they did not know.But respondents were ided on whether the 2016 referendum result gave the prime minister a mandate to leave the EU without a deal, with 34 per cent believing it did and 36 per cent suggesting it did not.The new findings came as the People’s Vote campaign held a 700-strong rally at Bristol’s Colston Hall to demand a fresh referendum on the final Brexit deal. Attendees included Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable, senior Conservative MP Sarah Wollaston and Green MEP Molly Scott Cato.People's Vote march – demanding vote on final Brexit dealA young story: Created with Sketch.Not being seen as the establishment was key to Leave’s success in the 2016 referendumClick to followIndy PoliticsBrexit: Leave campaign no longer viewed as anti-establishment movement as Remainers turn to insurgent strategyThe campaign to Remain in the European Union is no longer overwhelmingly seen as the “establishment” movement in the Brexit debate, according to new polling.The survey by YouGov found that after months of the government negotiating to quit the EU, many British people see&nbspLeave&nbspas the establishment movement in the ongoing debate about the UK’s future.The finding is significant because at the 2016 referendum Leave was bolstered by its image as an anti-establishment crusade, while Remain was hindered by the perception that it was the campaign of the government and business elite.Leaders of the People’s Vote group, who commissioned the poll, told The Independent the shift will mark a change in their campaign strategy to more insurgent-style tactics.A senior source at People’s Vote said: “For too long our side of the argument has been, sometimes unfairly, seen as the establishment telling the people they got it wrong two years ago.“We now have the chance to give voice to millions of people who feel the establishment has screwed Brexit up over the past two years and want to take back control of the process through a People’s Vote.”The source added: “We will be making the case that the likes of Michael Gove are the establishment now – they are in power, they are doing this to you.” &nbspRees-Mogg suggests a second Brexit referendum would be acceptable in clip from 2011The YouGov poll&nbspof more than 10,000 people found that Leave campaigners are now regarded as “the establishment” by 34 per cent of voters, while those seeking to stay in the EU are regarded as such by 35 per cent.Asked if Leave campaigners understood the concerns of ordinary people, 27 per cent said they did while 54 disagreed. The figures for campaigns seeking to stay in the EU were 26 per cent and 52 per cent.Brexit: Half of Britons want final say in no-deal scenario, poll findsPochettino blames Brexit and new stadium costs for Tottenham’s windowUK’s richest man and ardent Brexiteer moving to MonacoPound sterling- latest updates: Exchange rates hit by Brexit fearsI want to leave the EU but I support a Final Say on the Brexit dealThe Independent has launched its own Final Say campaign, to win British people the right to hold a new referendum on Brexit, setting up a petition that has now attracted some 600,000 signatures.On Saturday, the first regional People’s Vote rally will take place in Bristol at a sell-out event in the city’s Colston Hall.The event will feature speakers from the Conservative, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties, as well as local activists.Our Future, Our Choice, the largest youth group campaigning for another referendum, will be spraying “clean graffiti” on Bristol’s streets – using a power washer and stencil to inscribe their message on grimy paving and walls.Further rallies are planned throughout the summer in Edinburgh, Newcastle, Cambridge, Cardiff, Liverpool, Birmingham and London.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Just one in four trust parliament with the decision as ‘no deal’ looms according to 10,000 strong poll sampleClick to followIndy PoliticsBrexit: Half of Britons want final say in no-deal scenario, major new poll findsHalf of Britons want a referendum on leaving the European Union if Brexit talks collapse and the country faces leaving with no deal, a major new poll has revealed.The huge study carried out by YouGov, which surveyed a weighted sample of more than 10,000 people, found just a quarter want parliament to be given the final decision.The key finding comes as concern over a no-deal Brexit increases, precipitating a slump in sterling&nbspamid news that the UK government is stockpiling food and medicine.The findings are&nbspalso a major boost to the People’s Vote campaign for a new referendum, which commissioned the poll, and The Independent’s own Final Say campaign – which has attracted more than half a million signatories to its petition.The survey also shines a light on views of Brexit’s progress, with large majorities thinking talks are going poorly, that the process of leaving has been a mess, that the country would end up with a bad deal and that the British government would bear responsibility.Former president of YouGov Peter Kellner said: “If the Brexit negotiations with Brussels break down, a two to one majority of voters want the public, not parliament, to decide what happens.“Even people who voted Leave tend to prefer a new referendum, by 39-34 per cent. This is politically significant.Rees-Mogg suggests a second Brexit referendum would be acceptable in clip from 2011“There is clearly the potential for a broadly based campaign this autumn for a people’s vote&nbspshould the Brussels talks go badly. Support for a new referendum would go well beyond the ranks of those who want to stop Brexit.”The pollsters asked “should the final decision be made by MPs voting in parliament or the public voting in a new referendum”, if the UK had to choose whether to remain in the EU or leave with no deal.It is now clear that the people are starting to find their voice and they demand a vote on the final Brexit deal as the only way out of this messHalf, 50 per cent, said the decision should be given to the public voting in a new referendum. story: Created with Sketch.'Our user community has been very devoted to us and it’s awful to think that we have let any of you down'Click to followThe Independent USTrump tariffs have forced us into bankruptcy and liquidation, says PC case maker CaseLabsA high-end PC case maker says it has been “forced into bankruptcy and liquidation” by tariffs introduced by Donald Trump.CaseLabs, which makes custom towers&nbspfor computers and has a high-profile following, including prominent YouTubers such as LinusTechTips, announced it would be permanently closing on Saturday.The company, based in California, said tariffs had raised costs by almost 80 per cent and that “the default of a large account” had added to the issue.“We are very sad to announce that CaseLabs and its parent company will be closing permanently,” CaseLabs said in a statement. “We have been forced into bankruptcy and liquidation.“The tariffs have played a major role raising prices by almost 80 per cent (partly due to associated shortages), which cut deeply into our margins.“The default of a large account added greatly to the problem. It hit us at the worst possible time.”The manufacturer is likely to be referring to US tariffs placed on Chinese goods.The dispute between the two countries has escalated since the US imposed 25 per cent duties on $34bn&nbsp(£31bn) of Chinese goods in early July in response to claims that China steals or pressures foreign companies to hand over technology.President&nbspTrump’s administration last week announced it would push ahead with 25 per cent tariffs on an additional $16bn of Chinese imports starting from 23 August.CaseLabs' headquarters in California, US (Google street view)China hit back by saying it would impose identical tariffs on $16bn of US goods, including cars, crude oil and scrap metal.Mr Trump also announced on Friday that he had doubled US tariffs on Turkish steel and aluminium as the value of the Turkish lira plunged.He said tariffs would be raised to 20 per cent for aluminium and 50 per cent for steel with respect to Turkey.CaseLabs, which was born out of parent company California Fabrication Company, set up in 1971, said it was doing its best to ship as many orders as possible but admitted it would not be able to ship them all.11-ft shark pictured leaping title: Perseid meteor shower live stream watch perseids 2018 online
story: The Perseid meteors are one of the most active meteor showers of the year with as many as 100 shooting stars&nbspappearing on an hourly rate.The meteor shower is known for producing exquisitely bright fireballs streaking across the skies during its short peak.The good news is you can watch the show here on Express, courtesy of the Virtual Telescope Project, without having to leave the comfort of your home.The annual Perseid shower peaks this weekend between the nights of Saturday, August 11, and the wee morning hours of Monday, August 13.Astronomers at US space agency NASA advised the Perseids will be at their most intense around&nbsp2am&nbsplocal time on Monday morning.But if the optimal viewing hours appear incredibly daunting the good news is all you have to do is click the embedded YouTube live stream below.The steam will kick off at exactly 8.30pm UTC or 9.30pm UK time.Gianluca Masi, director of the Italy-based Virtual Telescope Project, told Express the Perseid shower is something no astronomer would want to miss.Mr Masi said: &ldquoPerseids never disappoint the observer &ndash they are one of the best astronomical shows&nbspoff&nbspthe year and we just need our own eyes to see them. Easy and cheap.&ldquoLooking up for these meteors is a nice opportunity to discover the wonders of the sky and that there is beauty even in a fraction of a second.&ldquoSurely, experiencing this personally is the best choice, but if it is cloudy outside or unable to reach a suitable venue, the online view offered by the Virtual Telescope is a great backup.&ldquoYou see, you cannot miss the Perseids show.                Perseids 2018: How to watch - Will California fire smoke block view?The Virtual Telescope Perseids livestream will broadcast this year from the picturesque Perugia province in central Italy.The stream will come from a telescope mounted at the hamlet of Castel Santa Maria next to the ruins of a&nbsp16th century&nbspchurch.Weather permitting, viewing condition this year are expected to be practically perfect with no harsh moonlight to wash out the Perseids.The August lunar cycle is currently entering the darkened New Moon phase which should keep the starlit skies dark.Perseids 2018: Watch the spectacular meteor shower live stream online here (Image: NASAMEO&bull)Perseids 2018: The annual meteor shower peaks around mid-August each year (Image: )Dr Helen Klus, Royal Astronomical Society, told Express you might even be able to catch a glimpse of the meteors by peeking outside your window.The astronomy expert said: &ldquoThey should be much easier to see as they will be visible all across the sky everywhere in the Northern Hemisphere.&ldquoYou should be able to see them just by looking out of the window.&ldquoHowever they will look best if you go somewhere dark and look at the northeast.The Perseid meteors are the cosmic rubble and debris left behind in the orbital path of Comet Swift-Tuttle.Perseids 2018: The Perseids are known for their spectacular fireballs (Image: )Perseids 2018: The Perseids will peak around 2am local time on Monday, August 13 (Image: )The barrelling Haley-type comet completes a trip around the Sun every 133 years, leaving bits and pieces of space rock in its orbit.Every year between mid-July and the end of August the Earth approaches this littered cosmic highway and inidual space rocks enter the atmosphere.The meteors burn up above the planet, producing streaks of light and brilliant fireballs.The Perseids are named after their radiant point of origin in the constellation Perseus.

title: eclipse 2018 august partial solar eclipse watch online again
story: A partial solar eclipse graced the skies this morning (Image: )Depending on where you are in the world, you may have been able to witness the Moon slightly obscure the Sun in a partial solar eclipse today.Exclusively visible in the Northern Hemisphere - the Sun appeared to be shadowed by the Moon by up to 20 percent depending on your position.Viewers of solar eclipses are advised to never look directly at the Sun, and either wear specialised glasses or viewing boxes.A solar eclipse is damaging to the eyes as looking at the Sun can cause what&rsquos known as &lsquoeclipse blindness&rsquo.                Solar eclipse 2018 horoscope today: What does it mean?This is caused by retinal burns which occur when the powerful rays of the Sun damage cells in the back of the eye.A pinhole projection can also be one way to witness the solar eclipse without the danger of damaging your eyes.Making a pinhole in cardboard and holding it above a piece of paper on the ground can project the image of the solar eclipse without gazing at the Sun.Stargazers have had a treat in recent months, as this lunar event comes just 15 days after the July 27 Blood Moon.A Blood Moon occurs during a total lunar eclipse when the Earth passes between the Sun and Moon, plunging the Moon into shadow.The Moon then appears red due to light refraction in the Earth&rsquos atmosphere in which only reddy-orange hues can be seen - reflecting on the Moon&rsquos surface.There was another partial eclipse on Friday, July 13 but the lunar event had limited visibility.This morning the partial eclipse began at 8.02am UT (9.02am BST) with the Moon beginning to encroach on the Sun.                Eclipse 2018 astrology: Everything to know about August eclipse                Eclipse 2018: What time will the partial solar eclipse be visible o...The peak of the partial eclipse was at 9.46am UT (10.46am BST) and ended at 11.30am UT (12.30pm BST).The August eclipse began over the cold North Atlantic and Greenland before moving in a northeast direction.At the same time, the Moon&rsquos shadow appeared to move over Iceland and parts of Northern Europe and the North Pole.However, this eclipse was not visible in the UK or US - with visibility in China, North and South Korea and Mongolia.The eclipse wasn't able to be seen by many - but a Blood Moon will take place in January (Image: )The lunar event saw the Sun covered by the moon up to 20 percent (Image: )There was a live-stream of the eclipse, however, on YouTube channel The Eclipse Animator.This is available to re-watch here.For those disappointed they missed out on this eclipse, in less than six months time a full lunar eclipse will take place.On January 21, 2019, a Blood Moon will grace the skies and will be entirely visible across the UK, North and South America and Northwest Africa.

story: Celestial fireworks to spark up skies across the world (Image: Reuters)And stargazers could be in for a special treat on Saturday night as a new moon will make the sky even darker.Sunday night and before dawn on Monday will be the best time to watch the dazzling display - clouds permitting.The fireball bursts is caused by debris from Comet Swift-Tuttle when it comes into contact with the Earth&rsquos atmosphere.Anyone lucky enough to catch the extravaganza will see 80 meteors an hour.                Perseid meteor shower: Earth&rsquos atmosphere well protectedDr Robert Massey from the Royal Astronomical SocietyBut people living in cities may struggle more to catch the shower.Dr Robert Massey from the Royal Astronomical Society said: &ldquoThe shower will be visible all over the UK, as long as the skies are clear.&ldquoUnlike a lot of celestial events, meteor showers are easy to watch and no special equipment is needed, although a reclining chair and a blanket make viewing much more comfortable.The meteors are called Perseids because they appear from the Perseus constellation.They can reach speeds of up to 132,000 miles an hour.Affelia Wibisono, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said: &ldquoObservers are in luck this year as it coincides with the moon setting shortly after sunset to leave a dark night sky.&ldquoLight pollution greatly decreases the number of meteors visible so head out to the countryside and let your eyes become dark adapted by not looking at any bright lights for at least 15 minutes.&nbspThe comet orbits the Sun every 133 years, with the meteors - the size of a grain of sand - burning up when they hit the atmosphere at 36 miles per second.                Perseid meteor shower: 'TEARS of Biblical saint' to RAIN DOWNThe Perseid meteor shower will light up skies across the world this weekend (Image: REUTERSHeinz-Peter Bader  )NASA's telescopes in Daytona Beach, Florida caught the first signs of the celestial fireworks before they peak this weekend.The annual Perseid shower starts around mid-July when the Earth approaches the rubble-filled path of Comet Swift-Tuttle.But the meteor shower does not fully awaken until around mid-August when the Perseids peak in intensity.

title: Brexit news Iain Duncan Smith CBI migration policy new system plan EU withdrawal latest
story: Former Tory leader and Brexit supporter Iain Duncan Smith suggested the UK could extend the work permit process after Brexit to ensure Britain has an effective immigration system.A report from the powerful Commons Home Affairs committee has seen MPs from both sides of the debate unite over criticising the vacuum in government policy on the crucial issue.Speaking to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Duncan Smith put forward his proposal: I think the best thing to do is work with what we have got and make it work for everyone around the worldYou basically extend the work permit process across the EU and the rest of the world. People can come here for work but they need to have work to come to and that work needs to have been agreed and accepted that there isn't a person in the UK that could do that work and has the skills to do that work.                Brexiteer MP warns of 'UPROAR' if THIS key Brexit pledge not delivered                Merkel CLINGS to her job: Spain accepts German migration dealMr Duncan Smith also insisted the Government should make sure to reduce the alleged pull factors driving European Union citizens to relocate to Britain.He continued: In the last year figures were available, and this is important, more than &pound4.1 billion was spent on people from the EU who have come over here getting tax credits, child benefits, housing benefits. That's one of the great pull factors.Leaving the EU, we should not be offering for people to come over here just looking for work and to claim benefits.We need a living wage that does not require people to come over here and claim benefits to top up.The British Government has yet to publish its plans for a new post-Brexit migration system nearly two years after the EU referendum.Brexit news: IDS called on the Government to  (Image: )The lack of planning spurred the Home Affairs Committee to condemn the lack of a policy direction as &ldquoregrettable and a &ldquomissed opportunity.The report noted: &ldquoContinued delays to the publication of the White Paper on Immigration and the Immigration Bill has meant there is little indication of what immigration policy will be.&ldquoDespite the fact that the issue was subject to heated and isive debate during the referendum campaigns in 2016 the Government has not attempted to build consensus on immigration reform or consult the public over future migration policy in the two years since.The Committee has warned that migration policy &ldquonow risks being caught up in a rushed and highly politicised debate in the run-up to the vote on the withdrawal agreement.The Chamber of British Commerce (CBI) has instead urged the Government to scrap blunt targets for immigration after Brexit, calling for a new freedom of movement system to be adopted.CBI deputy chief Josh Hardie said: This is no longer a theoretical debate, it's about the future of our nations.&nbspFalse choices and sloganeering must be avoided at all costs. Openness and control must not be presented as opposites.&nbspPublic attitudes towards migration and the impact it has on communities are far more nuanced.He added: Scrapping blunt targets, ensuring all who come to the UK contribute and using the immigration idend to support public services will add to public confidence.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May Conservative Party London European Union Hornchurch
story: Theresa May&rsquos Brexit White Paper has sparked fury in the Conservative Party and led to a series of resignation in the Government, including that of the former Brexit Secretary David Davis and the former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.Express visited the Conservative Party Association of Hornchurch and Upminster, an area which voted heavily to Leave the European Union, to see what they made of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan.Bob Perry, Chairman of the Hornchurch and Upminster Conservative Association claimed the Prime Minister&rsquos plan was &ldquonot Brexit before warning the blueprint could place the Tory party in &ldquomuddy water for years to come.When asked about how the Government was handling negotiations, Mr Perry said: &ldquoVery badly. Personally, I would have handled it a lot differently, but then I am not a parliamentarian so it is not for me to say how would we do that.                IDS puts forward BRILLIANT proposal for post-Brexit immigration system&ldquoBut, I think we should have had a Plan A and a Plan B in place, long before now.&ldquoMy main concern is the White Paper, it is not Brexit. We are still tied to ECJ rules, the common rulebook is an absolute farce.&ldquoIt&rsquos purely for the European Communities benefit and not ours. We have got no input in it. No say in it and we are bound by its future rules.&ldquoTo me, that is not Brexit. We voted to leave the European Union and this is just not delivering that.He added: &ldquoIf this goes ahead, and the people don&rsquot get a clean Brexit, I&rsquom not talking about a no-deal, but if we do not get a clean Brexit, then the Conservative Party are in very very muddy waters for generations to come.The Chairman of the Conservative Association also said that the Brexit White Paper had led to nearly a dozen members walking away from the association.He said: &ldquoWe have lost 10-12 members since the White Paper was published. I think we have had three people join us since. Obviously possibly Remainers.&ldquoThis constituency voted 71.9 percent to leave the European Union. We can&rsquot sell this to the people here.&ldquoA, because I don&rsquot believe in it, and B, because it is not Brexit, it clearly isn&rsquot Brexit.The frustrated tone was also clear from the President and Treasurer of the Hornchurch and Conservative Association, Keith Wells.The former councillor said: &ldquoI am not very happy, not very happy.&ldquoWhat I feel on this issue is that we as the public of this country made a vote, we voted on issues, and we weren&rsquot naive, we all basically knew what was going on because we were sent a letter explaining what Europe meant, what it would be doing, what it wouldn&rsquot be doing.&ldquoPeople voted on that issue and, as I say, what is happening at the moment is I don&rsquot believe the Government is enacting what the public feel.He added: &ldquoPeople are saying to me, what is happening with Brexit?Brexit news: The councillor said Mrs May is costing the Conservative Party (Image:  &bull Express)&ldquoWe voted on the referendum, we won by a majority, but unfortunately what we stated and how the vote went, the Government is not reacting on that situation, and that is why we are disappointed.Similarly, Henry Frost, who has been a Conservative voter all of his life, is also angry with Theresa May&rsquos Brexit plan.Mr Frost added that he thought the Conservative Party could be in the &ldquowilderness for years if cutting ties with Brussels is not delivered properly.He said: &ldquoBritain voted exit, from the European Community, that is what our party has got to deliver.Joe Webster, a former Conservative councillor explained his frustration at those MPs not delivering what the British people voted for.He said: &ldquoParliament abrogated the decision, they said &lsquooh I don&rsquot think we can make up our minds, let the people decide&rsquo. So they put it out for a referendum.&ldquoNow, it comes back that we want to leave, and the whole of parliament, therefore, should to some extent, be behind working for leave.&ldquoWhat annoys me is, not only parliament but also some members of the Conservative Party are actually wanting to overturn that. With another referendum.&ldquoWell, we don&rsquot want another referendum. A referendum is a referendum, people have made the decision, it is up to the Government now to work out a good deal, for us.It comes as the Prime Minister is sticking with her Chequers plan, despite the European Union&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator already picking holes in the plan.Mrs May cut her summer holiday short last week to meet with French President Emmanuel Macron to try to persuade him to come around to her blueprint.The Prime Minister has sent a letter to Tory members, insisting her Chequers strategy does not represent a concession to Brussels.In the letter, obtained by the Conservative Home website, the Prime Minister conceded that last month's Brexit White Paper had provoked strong feelings within the party.She wrote: This vision for our future relationship with the EU will be very challenging for the EU - it is in no sense a concession to their demands.I have been very clear that we are rejecting the two models they have put forward.&ldquoInstead, we are asking them to accept a bespoke model which meets the unique requirements of the United Kingdom.

story: Ben Bishop found a Elizabethan signet ring that is set to make up to &pound10,000 at auction (Image: HANSONS)Ben, 30, from Bridgwater, Somerset, said: &ldquoI wasn&rsquot expecting to find anything except a few coins, buckles or buttons.&ldquoI thought it was another Coke can ring-pull &ndash I&rsquove found tons of those over the years along with lots of rubbish.&ldquoBut I saw something shining and, when I broke off the mud, this beautiful ancient gold ring appeared before my eyes.&ldquoIt is something I will remember forever.&ldquoIt&rsquos the first gold I&rsquove ever found. I was so gobsmacked I just sat down on the ground staring at it for about 40 minutes.                Slab of gold nicknamed 'lightning bolt' expected to sell for 80K                 Guillotine and electric chair up for sale in grisly auctionThe ring was unearthed last August in a farmer&rsquos field near Glastonbury, Somerset, where Ben, a metal detectorist for seven years, had permission to dig. He registered the find as treasure trove but it was returned to him after examination. Throne Now the gold signet ring, featuring a double-headed eagle, will be sold at Hansons Auctioneers in Derbyshire on September 27 with an estimate of &pound7,500 to &pound10,000. Signet rings were used to mark a wax seal on documents identifying who was sending them. Ben, a factory technician, said: &ldquoI thought it may have been Eastern European but it turns out that the eagle symbol was used on lead tokens when Elizabeth I was on the throne.&ldquoThe ring was taken away for a couple of months to be examined and the British Museum did a report on it. No museums wanted to buy it so it was returned to me as the finder.The ring was unearthed last August in a farmer&rsquos field near Glastonbury (Image: HANSONS)&ldquoI had an agreement with the owner of the field that if I found anything of high value I would sell it and split the proceeds. &ldquoIt&rsquos a man&rsquos ring and fits my finger really well, but I have to part with it. &ldquoI have no idea who it originally belonged to but it would have been a person of wealth and importance. Glastonbury Abbey isn&rsquot far away. Gems expert Kate Bliss of TV&rsquos Bargain Hunt and Flog It! said of the find &ndash confirmed as Elizabethan and dated to between 1550 and 1650: &ldquoThis gold signet ring bowled me over. &ldquoDepicting a double headed eagle on a flat oval bezel with beaded border, the ring weighs in at an unusually heavy 17gm. Ben said: &ldquoI don&rsquot do this for the money &ndash I love history. England is one of the biggest treasure troves because we have so much history on these isles and things were so well-made in past times. &ldquoI will be a metal dectectorist for the rest of my life.

title: theme park blackgang chine uk oldest park
story: BIG THRILLS..... One of the park&rsquos amazing animatronic dinosaurs (Image: Blackgang Chine)When Alexander Dabell cast a stone in 1843 to determine the reach of his lease on a windswept cliff in the Isle of Wight, Queen Victoria had been on the throne for just five years.&nbspGold would not be discovered in California for another five years and the world&rsquos first stamp &ndash the Penny Black &ndash had been in circulation for just three years.&nbspStretching about three quarters of a mile down to the shore from 500 feet above sea level, the land he wanted to buy was a wild and desolate gorge frequented by fishermen and riven with rumours of a thriving smuggling trade.&nbspBut Alexander, who saw himself as a pioneer in &ldquothis far flung barbarous climb, was determined to make his fortune by founding Britain&rsquos first amusement park there.                Thorpe Park power cut: Hundreds TRAPPED on rides in sweltering 35C                 Chessington World of Adventures CLOSED due to burst water pipeThis year Black-gang Chine, named after the coastal ravine where it is located on the island&rsquos wild southern shore, will celebrate its 175th birthday.&nbspIn the process it has become the blueprint for all the UK&rsquos theme parks. In some cases, quite literally.&nbsp&ldquoBlackgang opened before teabags had been invented and we quite often see ideas of ours popping up in other theme parks, says owner Alec Dabell, who is named after his great-great-grandfather.&nbsp&ldquoOne chap was saying how it is hard in our business to generate new ideas.&nbsp&ldquoBut I&rsquove got 25 years-worth of ideas already and I&rsquom growing exponentially. What I really need to invent is a machine to make more time.&nbspOne of his most recent ideas is a pond with a footpath through the middle enabling you to get a frog&rsquos-eye view of the lily pads.&nbspThere are also singing English dodos, a hall of mirrors, original rides, and the country&rsquos biggest animatronic T-Rex.&nbspBlackgang also has another illustrious claim to fame as the oldest continuously open amusement park in the world.&nbspBlackgang Chine visitors in 1922 (Image: Blackgang Chine)&ldquoDuring the war years the two slightly older ones, in occupied Denmark and Austria, closed but we remained open, he declares.&ldquoOf course we did! We were British and we didn&rsquot shut just because of a bit of adversity. As my grandmother used to say, &lsquoIf the Luftwaffe are overhead then you just lie still and pretend you&rsquore a cow pat&rsquo.&nbspThis is no idle boast.&nbspGerman planes during the Second World War frequently jettisoned unused bombs over the Isle of Wight following attacks on the nearby docks at Portsmouth and Southampton.&nbspAs a little boy Alec, who has an MBA and returned to the island five years ago after a career in the City, grew up in the ultimate playground.&nbsp&ldquoI had my own cowboy town and didn&rsquot everyone have dinosaurs in the bottom of their garden? How could anyone not have these things?&nbsp&ldquoFrom a little boy it&rsquos all I&rsquove ever known. My father is 94 and he put in the dinosaurs in the 1970s.&nbsp&ldquoI remember sitting on the sofa at home saying, &lsquoCan we have some dinosaurs?&rsquo and a year later along they came.&nbspOne of Alec&rsquos earliest memories is flying in a helicopter hired by BBC&rsquos Blue Peter who had come to witness the first batch of prehistoric creatures being craned in.&nbsp&ldquoI discovered that John Noakes smoked like a chimney but the real wonder was Mother Nature. Looking up at a dinosaur model and saying, &lsquoDaddy when you said it was big, you didn&rsquot say it was that big!&rsquo&ldquoAnd you can&rsquot argue with that.&nbspA few years ago Alec launched Restricted Area 5 and filled it with the largest animatronic dinosaurs in the UK, made to his specification in China.&nbspIn this way he continues to follow in the footsteps of his namesake who knew it would be possible to create gardens that would appeal to the romantic Victorians but sensed that he needed to offer something more.&ldquoWhen he started children were still seen and not heard, the Battle of Waterloo was barely over and tourism hadn&rsquot been invented.&ldquoIf I&rsquod been able to ask my great-great-grandfather how big the car park was he would have said, &lsquoWhat&rsquos a car?&rsquo Back then there wasn&rsquot such a thing as a business model but there was that really positive Victorian spirit that defied convention.&nbspShortly after Alexander bought his ravine a huge fin whale got stranded off The Needles, the most westerly point of the island and the showman saw his chance.&nbsp                Best theme parks in the UK revealed by TripAdvisor                 Rollercoaster HORROR as girl killed when &lsquopendulum ride&rsquo CRASHESHe bought it at auction, sold off the blubber, had the bones bleached and displayed the skeleton to the morbid curiosity of all who visited.&nbsp&ldquoBefore then you could read in a book how big a whale was but the chances were that you had never seen one or come across one, points out Alec.&nbspIt proved an instant hit and the park received the ultimate endorsement 10 years later when Queen Victoria herself came to view it.&nbsp&ldquoIn fact, she came four or five years in a row. Interestingly, 20 years or so later she offered a great deal of input into the building and the exhibits in the new Natural History Museum. As to where she got her ideas I couldn&rsquot possibly comment.&nbspBut he won&rsquot be drawn on current famous visitors.&nbsp&ldquoThere are various well known celebrities but we don&rsquot talk about them. We allow them to be the child within while they are here. That&rsquos the magic of Black-gang.&nbspAnd that alternative way of looking at things is Alec&rsquos raison d&rsquoetre.&nbspHe describes the thrill he gets from seeing the joy on visitors&rsquo faces and the pleasure returning customers gain from stepping back into their childhoods with their own grandchildren.&nbspOwner Alec Dabell said he has 25 years-worth of theme park ideas (Image: Blackgang Chine)&ldquoYou get to be that little girl or boy again and if you feel younger you are younger, insists Alec, who is reluctant to disclose his own age (57) &ndash it&rsquos the only moment during our interview when his energy dips.&nbsp&ldquoOh, age is such a grown-up thing and I&rsquom still playing and that&rsquos what I want to encourage other people to do, he explains.&nbspOne of the grown-up issues that this Peter Pan and his forebears have had to face is the erosion which has seen vast chunks of the amusement park lost to the sea over the years at nearly four metres per year.&nbsp&ldquoMy great-great-grandfather may not have been much of a structural engineer or have had any understanding of soil types but you wouldn&rsquot want to move it anywhere else.&nbspBeing here, I just can&rsquot help but smile. The sea breeze is nature&rsquos air conditioning.&nbspAnyway, we adapt and move inland and I reckon we&rsquove got enough land left for at least another 175 years, he insists.A few years ago Alec was at a conference of theme park directors and met one of Walt Disney&rsquos original &ldquoimagineers who recalled being at the opening of Disneyland in the 1950s.&ldquoI said, &lsquoExcuse me sir, but do you realise that by then we were already more than 100 years old?&rsquo&nbspThey would give their eye teeth to have what we take for granted. But if I&rsquove learned anything it&rsquos that we have to be a bit more grown-up about telling people we are here.&nbspFor more information visit blackgangchine

title: Brexit news Bim Afolami second referendum UK EU withdrawal Chequers Theresa May
story: Tory MP Bim Afolami yesterday dismissed calls for a new Brexit referendum as he insisted a new vote would be rigged with flaws.British political figures such as Labour MP Chuka Umunna and Tory Remainer Anna Soubry joined forces in April to launch the People's Vote campaign in favour of a vote on the final withdrawal terms agreed to with the European Union.&nbspBut Mr Afolami trashed the arguments for a new vote as he spoke on BBC programme Any Questions?: The second referendum does have a huge number of problems with it.I think there would be a huge amount of disagreement about what the question would be, whether it would be one stage or two stage.                'It's not the WAR!' CEO dismantles claims UK will run out of supplies The Tory MP added that a new vote on Brexit would not actually unite the country but spur the losers to demand yet another referendum.He continued: You&rsquod then have an issue around what happens if Remain wins. Seriously, lots of people would say &lsquowe should do best of three.&rsquo What do you do then?I really don&rsquot see a scenario in which a second referendum is likely or preferable.Mr Afolami also took the chance to voice his support for Theresa May and her Chequers Brexit blueprint, asking for Britons to wait and see before striking it down.Brexit news: Bim Afolami dismissed calls for a fresh vote on EU membership (Image: PARLIAMENT TV&bull)Mr Afolami concluded: Before December, when we got the phase one withdrawal agreement, all sorts of people said &lsquothere&rsquos no way we&rsquoll get there,&rsquo and we got there. Before March, when we got the transition agreement agreed lots of people said &lsquowe wouldn&rsquot get it,&rsquo and we got there.All I&rsquom asking is let&rsquos wait and see what the Government can produce by the end of this year or this autumn as a result of the discussion with the European Union.I personally strongly back the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers agreement, I think it&rsquos sensible. I think it puts jobs first, I think it puts families first.Mrs May, who is still trying to convince the public and EU leaders of her Chequers plans&rsquo proficiency, could be asked to sign even more concessions in Brussels ahead of the UK&rsquos imminent ceasing of free movement and trade.It was reported that the UK&rsquos future relationship with the EU would echo the bloc&rsquos relationship with Jersey and other Channel Islands - and allow the UK to keep a single market for goods.Government sources revealed on Thursday it was clear there had been a &ldquoshift in language from the EU following the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers proposals.While Brussels would be disobeying its own rules to offer the deal, the price of the deal would be high for Britain which would have to accept the bloc&rsquos rules on social policy, environmental regulations and customs rules.This would allow the EU to continue with its project of seizing control of the UK pensions market, benefits and would prevent any meaningful free trade deals with the rest of the world.

story: Sky News presenter Niall Paterson fired back at anti-Brexit Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable as he once more urged the Government to hold a new vote ahead of a rally in Bristol.After claiming British voters were not aware of the consequences of leaving the European Union, Mr Paterson said: You see, the thing is Mr Cable you can&rsquot say people weren&rsquot warned.During the referendum campaign I remember people, predominantly on your side of the debate, saying &lsquolook, a no deal is potentially possible, we are going to see effects for business.&rsquoPeople knew all of this and yet they still voted to come out of the European Union. story: The pair attended the Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo on Friday (Image: NC)The Scots actor held hands with his Fargo co-star, Mary Elizabeth Winstead, as his brother Colin, an ex-RAF pilot, opened proceedings by reading the war poem, High Flight.Father-of-four McGregor, 47, announced he&rsquod split from wife Eve Mavrakis last year after photos emerged of him kissing the 33-year-old American in a London cafe, while she also orced her husband, Riley Stearns.The Trainspotting star cited &ldquoirreconcilable differences when he filed for orce to end his 22-year marriage in January.Although the pair were barely on speaking terms, they were reunited in May for eldest daughter Clara&rsquos graduation.                &lsquoWhat will Dad think?&rsquo Ewan McGregor's girl Clara STRIPS for PLAYBOYFather-of-four McGregor, 47, announced he&rsquod split from wife Eve Mavrakis last year (Image: )McGregor and Winstead were expected to appear together at the London premiere of his latest film, Christopher Robin, last week but he was instead joined on the red carpet by parents Carol and James.She was absent from the event after 22-year-old Clara called her dad&rsquos girl-friend a &ldquopiece of trash on social media.Following the premiere, McGregor said he&rsquod taken nine months off filming to spend time with his children, including Jamyan 17, Esther, 16 and seven-year-old Anouk, and for &ldquotinkering with old cars.Colin, 49, joined the glamorous pair in the Royal Gallery to watch this year&rsquos spectacle, The Sky&rsquos the Limit, following his moving tribute to the late servicemen and women of the RAF. title: california volcano USGS Long Valley Caldera supervolcano
story: The amount of magma in the Long Valley Caldera is so large it could support an eruption equivalent to the massive one which occurred 767,000 years ago, which released 140 cubic miles of material into the atmosphere.By comparison, the 1980 Mount St Helens eruption resulted in the release of 0.29 cubic miles.While the Long Valley Caldera is unlikely to blow anytime soon, the report, written by scientists from the United States Geological Survey (USGS), the University of California, and the University of Rhode Island, said: &ldquoWe can conclude the mid-crustal reservoir is still melt-rich.&ldquoWe estimate the reservoir currently contains enough melt to support another super eruption comparable in size to the caldera-forming eruption at 767 ka.The report, published by the Geological Society of America, stresses however that there is no need to start panicking, adding: &ldquoThis volume and a relatively high melt fraction in no way ensures that the magma is eruptible.The team used cutting-edge techniques to inspect the volcano in great detail, enabling them to reach their stunning conclusions.The Long Valley Caldera is one of the Earth's largest calderas, measuring about 20 miles long, 11 miles wide and up to 3,000 feet (910 m) deep.After four strong earthquakes shook the Long Valley area in 1980, USGS scientists also detected evidence of renewed volcanic unrest in the region.&nbspThey subsequently found that the central part of caldera was slowly rising.A thermal image of the Long Valley Caldera (Image: Geological Society of America)Scientists used high-tech equipment to examine the supervolcano in detail (Image: Geological Society of America)A fact sheet issued by the USGS states: &ldquoBecause such ground deformation and earthquakes are common precursors of volcanic eruptions, the USGS has continued to closely monitor the unrest in this region.It is natural to wonder when and where the next volcanic eruption might occur in the Long Valley area. Geologic processes generally proceed at a slow pace, and when viewed on the scale of a human lifetime, volcanic eruptions and destructive earthquakes happen rarely.&ldquoNevertheless, the long history of volcanic activity in the Long Valley area indicates that future eruptions will occur.Geologists have found that after its creation in the massive eruption 760,000 years ago, clusters of smaller volcanic eruptions have occurred in the caldera at roughly 200,000-year intervals.&nbsp                Yellowstone: experts confirm 'anomaly' - 'no need for concern' as v...Long Valley Caldera erupted spectacularly 767,000 years ago (Image: )About 100,000 years ago, the most recent of these eruptions formed the Mammoth Knolls, low hills just north of the Town of Mammoth Lakes.Mammoth Mountain, a young volcano on the rim of Long Valley Caldera, was created by a series of eruptions which occurred between 220,000 and 50,000 years ago.&nbspVolcanoes in the Mono-Inyo Craters volcanic chain, which extends from just south of Mammoth Mountain to the north shore of Mono Lake in Mono County, California, have erupted frequently over the course of the last 40,000 years.&nbspDuring the last 5,000 years, an eruption has occurred somewhere along this chain every 250 to 700 years.&nbspThe nearby Inyo Craters and associated lava domes were the result of a series of small to moderate eruptions 550 to 600 years ago, while the most recent eruptions along the volcanic chain took place about 250 years ago at Paoha Island in Mono Lake.The fact sheet added: &ldquoWhen an eruption does break out in the Long Valley area, its impact will depend on the location, size, and type of eruption, as well as the wind direction.&ldquoAlso, an eruption during the winter months could melt heavy snow packs, generating mudflows and locally destructive flooding.David Rothery, Professor of Planetary Geosciences at the Open University, told Express: &ldquoA major eruption in the next 100 years is extremely unlikely, but a there is a greater than 50 percent chance of major eruption in the next few hundred thousand years.The report, authored by Ashton F Flinders, David R Shelly, Philip B Dawson, David P Hill, Barbara Tripoli, and Yang Shen, states: &ldquoDespite 40 years of erse investigations, the presence of large volumes of melt in Long Valley&rsquos magma reservoir remain unresolved.&ldquoHere we show, through full waveform seismic tomography, a mid-crustal zone of low shear-wave velocity.

I think Brexit is the least of their difficulties. Greece is obviously desperately unhappy with the situation it finds itself in.You&rsquove got the Visegrad countries of Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and the Czech Republic increasingly working as a bloc, with concerns over the direction of travel, particularly on immigration.With all that on the background, there&rsquos going to be a change of Commission, there&rsquos going to be a change of President, there&rsquos a lot of change in the EU.If it doesn&rsquot change quickly and reflect what people are saying, I think it&rsquos got real difficulties in the future. I don&rsquot think Juncker gets the message.

story: Two US military jets were scrambled to chase the rogue pilot, who slammed the plane onto the sparsely populated island.There was no indication that the incident was an act of terror, the local Pierce County Sheriff's Department has said.No passengers were onboard at the time of the crash.The sheriff suggested the pilot may have been suicidal and said earlier that the man was a airline mechanic, but the airline said the employee was a ground service agent.A Horizon Air ground service agent got into a Bombadier Q400 turboprop aircraft on Friday night in a maintenance area at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport.&nbsp                WATCH: US Fighter jet give chase to STOLEN Alaska Air plane                 Shock aftermath shows 'suicidal' Seattle plane burst into flamesHorizon sister carrier Alaska Airline said the man took off, flew for about an hour, often erratically, before crashing on Ketron Island in Puget Sound, about 25 miles to the southwest.&nbspPierce County Sheriff's Department said the 29 year-old man, who has not been named, was suicidal and appeared to have acted alone.&nbspIt added the employee was believed to have been killed in the crash, with nobody else hurt.Airline and airport officials said in a news conference that the employee had worked for Horizon Air for three-and-a-half years.The sheriff tweeted: Was doing stunts in air or lack of flying skills caused crash into Island.Two F-15s fighter jets pursued the plane but were not involved in the crash at Ketron Island, according to local TV station KIRO7 reported. Pilots kept plane out of harm's way and people on ground safe, the sheriff tweeted.Video footage on social media showed a large plane flying above the Seattle area with an F-15 following it.SeaTac airport confirmed an airline member of staff took the plane.In a statement, the airport said: &ldquoAn airline employee conducted an unauthorized takeoff without passengers at Sea-Tac aircraft has crashed in south Puget SoundEarlier, the local Sherriff&rsquos office suggested the pilot of the stolen plane was a mechanic or other person with minimal flying experience.Pierce County Sheriff confirmed on Twitter: &ldquoPreliminary info is that a mechanic from unknown airlines stole plane. Was doing stunts in air or lack of flying skills caused crash into Island.The unidentified 29-year-old ground service agent was pronounced dead at the scene, according to the&nbspPierce County Sheriff Paul Pastor.Although the identity of the man is not known, authorities have confirmed that he was in charge of&nbspdirecting aircraft for takeoff, gate approach and de-icing planes.During an extraordinary exchnage with air traffic controllers, the man can be heard saying he was just a broken guy and joking about becoming a pilot if he landed safely.                REVEALED: How to survive a plane crash                Can you survive a plane crash on water? Surprising secret revealedThe air traffic controller, who called the man 'Rich,' tried to convince the man to land the airplane.The&nbspcontroller&nbspsaid: There is a runway just off to your right side in about a mile.The rogue pilot replied: Oh man. Those guys will rough me up if I try and land there. This is probably jail time for life, huh?I've got a lot of people that care about me. It's going to disappoint them to hear that I did this.Just a broken guy, got a few screws loose, I guess.A passenger on an airplane that was taxing off before the incident tweeted: Okay this insane. A pilot on the plane in front of us just went rogue and took off on an empty plane bypassing orders from the tower. The tower ordered a full stop and they&rsquore trying to communicate with that pilot. Whaaaaaat!In a later statement, they also reaffirmed the incident was not terror related and the pilot was the only passenger aboard.The sheriff tweeted:Told F-15s made it within a few minutes of theft of plane. Pilots kept plane out of harm's way and people on ground safe.Video footage and photographs appear to show a plane flying low followed by F15s, and a short time later, plumes of smoke.The Federal Aviation Administration, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the incident, said Brad Tilden, the CEO of Alaska Air Group.Fighter jets responded to the plane that went rogue (Image: REUTERS)Aerial images show fire burning on Ketron Island. Alaska Airlines have confirmed an incident with one of their aircraft.In a statement on Twitter the airline said: &ldquoWe are aware of an incident involving an unauthorized take-off of a Horizon Air Q400. We believe there are no passengers on board.The Bombardier Q400 turboprop airplane is designed for shorter-distance flights and can seat 76 passengers, Alaska Air said on its website.Seattle Tacoma or SeaTac is the ninth busiest airport in the US.

title: italy news european union italy debt eu spending giuseppe conte
story: According to an unsourced report in Italy&rsquos la Republic newspaper on Saturday, Brussels is finally prepared to give the Italian Government some financial leeway in the escalating row.&nbspIn return, the EU wants a commitment from Italy to reduce its structural deficit, which is adjusted for economic growth fluctuations.&nbspItaly&rsquos populist coalition wants enough flexibility to introduce a flat tax and a citizen&rsquos income in next year&rsquos budget without running foul of EU budget restrictions.The latest development comes after Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte sent a stern warning to European figureheads, vowing to safeguard the country&rsquos economic interests against ones from the bloc in order to tackle the huge debt it faces.                Salvini threatens to veto EU plans as he reveals list of demands                EUROZONE ON BRINK: Italy and Spain STILL suffering from 2008 crisisIn July, Italy&rsquos &euro2.1 trillion debt increased by 1.6 points, making it the third highest debt-ridden state after Belgium, which has shown a 2.9 point increase, and Greece, up 1.8 points, according to figures from Eurostat.&nbspBut the Government has still promised to increase benefit spending and tax cuts, plans that could cost as much as &euro120 billion in the first full year.Speaking at a press conference in Rome on Friday before the summer recess, Mr Conte vowed his Government would be very serious in its demands to Brussels.&nbspHe told reporters:&nbsp&ldquoYou should bear in mind that so far in all our meetings with our European partners and the EU institutions, I never asked for any favours.&ldquoWe have already spoken about economic issues and we have already put forward some of the red lines in our economic plan.The EU is finally set to buckle under intense pressure from Giuseppe Conte and his Government (Image: )&ldquoWe will go to Brussels with our heads held high with a strong, reasonable and brave programme.&ldquoA programme that will safeguard Italy&rsquos interests, not theirs.&nbspOn this, we will be very, very serious.Both Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio and Interior Minister Matteo Salvini have already warned the European Union that Italy would employ tough tactics to win concessions.&nbspIn an interview with Aljazeera, Mr Salvini&nbspwarned that Italy would be prepared to veto any future decisions that will not be taken in the interests of its economic future.He said: &ldquoWe have put many issues on Brussels&rsquo table to be discussed in the coming months.Salvini blames EU as farmers are 'forced' to resort to illegalityItalian PM promises showdown in Brussels to tackle state's huge debtMatteo Salvini had issued a stern warning to Brussels on its economic future (Image: )&ldquoWe aim at working in the next few weeks towards a mutual agreement.&ldquoBut if we are forced to veto decisions as our last resource, we will.Mr Di Maio suggested that if the EU changed the way deficit is calculated, then the Government&rsquos plans could be implemented without breaching EU budget restrictions.&nbspHe said: &ldquoWe want to discuss these reforms with the European Union to obtain the margin for maneuver that will allow us to implement those measures.&nbsp&ldquoThat means doing the same as we did on immigration. There shouldn&rsquot be a clash with the EU, but a frank discussion.Luigi Di Maio said there shouldn't be a clash with the EU, but a frank discussion (Image: )Earlier on Saturday, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said his coalition Government will introduce a raft of structural reforms this autumn, reiterating that next year&rsquos budget would be &ldquoserious rigorous and courageous.&nbspAmong the planned measures are a simplification of rules surrounding the awarding of public works contracts, a new anti-corruption drive and move to accelerate the justice system.&nbspMr Conte also promised a reform of the country&rsquos tax code, and the introduction of the &lsquocitizens wage&rsquo, which would ensure income of up to &euro780 per month for the poor.&nbspMost of the measures could be laid out in detail during next year&rsquos budget, and must be presented to the EU by mid-October.&nbsp&nbsp

title: self harming kids online trolls jane moore
story: She smoked (fags and pot), she drank alcohol (often in front of her liberal parents), always had what my mother would consider to be unsuitable boyfriends and was effortlessly academic, particularly at maths.Often, as we walked home from school chatting away, she would casually drag the back of her hand along a brick wall, causing the flesh to swell angrily and bleed.Other times she’d quietly press a lit cigarette into her palm, her expression never changing.“Why do you do that?” I’d ask.“It makes me feel better,” she’d say with a shrug.Sarah (not her real name) was, as I now know it, a self-harmer. But in those days — the late Seventies — it was rare and unrecognised.We lost touch a long time ago, but I thought of Sarah this week when I read that the number of teenage girls self-harming has doubled in the past 20 years.According to new NHS data, the number of hospital admissions for girls who have self-harmed has jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. For boys, the figures have stayed almost the same — from 2,236 then to 2,332 now.Worse, “self-poisoning” — as in taking an overdose — is rising for both genders and last month the Government released a green paper that said around 850,000 children and young people now have a diagnosable mental health condition.Experts say academic pressure is a contributory factor, so too social media.Kids have always had exams to cope with but in the old days jealous and bitter remarks were confined to the dark corners of secret conversations or, at worst, scrawled on a toilet wall.Now these brave warriors have a keyboard and pseudonym behind which they can troll you for everyone to see.By my age, you know the vitriol probably comes from a bitter, 53-year-old virgin who lives in his mother’s spare bedroom. But when you’re still finding your way in the world, that poisonous undermining can worm its way inside your head and chip away at the confidence that acts as an armour in life.One self-harmer told me the pain of cutting his skin provided a welcome distraction from the “washing machine” rotations of negative thoughts constantly disturbing his peace of mind.The majority of them can be helped if it is spotted early enough and the expert assistance they need is then easy to access. And therein lies the problem.In 2016, Theresa May said the mental health of children was to be one of her priorities as PM, but since then Brexit has taken over and little has changed.The Government’s strategy is to train more teachers to spot the signs, appoint 7,000 more specialists to child mental health units and cut the waiting time for non-critical cases to be seen.But even if it happens, it won’t be enough.Parents must also remain vigilant for any marked change in their child’s personality or behaviour and the big social media companies have the technology to stop the majority of trolls — so they should be forced to use it.If all of the above doesn’t happen, the NHS has another mental health time bomb coming which will cost the taxpayer a fortune and have an even greater cost to the mental well-being of the next generation.WHEN TV baker Paul Hollywood started dating a 23-year-old barmaid from his local pub, they were quick to point out that their relationship only started after his marriage to wife Alex ended.But Alex is reportedly not buying this explanation and is planning to name Summer Monteys-Fullam in her £10million divorce battle.Whatever the truth, it remains the case that many couples conveniently consider only full sexual intercourse as adultery.But of course, cosy chats, lingering touches and come-hither looks are all it takes for any man with a wandering eye to recognise that, should he wish to jump ship, there’s a shiny new model waiting in the wings to rev up his sex life.Hallelujah for the wonderfully pragmatic Emma Thompson who, when asked about her marriage to the dreamily handsome Greg Wise, replied that they have had plenty of rough times.The secret to a happy relationship, she says, is the realisation that there will be unhappy times and that, if you manage to amble through to the other side: “It’s always better.”She adds: “I think people in long, happy marriages tell a lot of fibs, like, ‘Yes, it’s been marvellous’, whereas I say, ‘Sometimes it has been awful’.”If a relationship is deeply unhappy for a sustained period then, of course, get the hell out.But in these Tinder times of endlessly sweeping left in search of the “perfect” mate (who doesn’t exist) it’s invaluable when someone high profile points out that, more often than not, sticking with the one you’ve got works out in the end.Altogether now, “Love is a decision, not just a feeling.”Daisy-May Demetres smile lights up a room.Just eight years old, she was born without her lower legs and now uses two prosthetic blades that allow her to live as full a life as possible.She attends mainstream school, loves PE and has just been given a modelling contract with high street brand River Island.Yet, because of her disability, her parents Alex and Claire admit to feeling a “profound sadness” the day she was born and asked themselves what they had done wrong. And when, as a toddler, Daisy-May had to endure a painful, eight-hour operation on her stumps, Alex admits he turned to alcohol and gambling in a bid to numb his feelings of hopelessness.But by the time she was four, Daisy-May had mastered her blades and was doing cartwheels and headstands.Alex, 35, from Birmingham, says: “I looked at her and thought, ‘If you can achieve so much, against all the odds, and still be cheerful, then I have no reason at all to be depressed’. I stopped gambling and drinking that day.”While no one would wish disability on their child, the Demetres’ story is a salutary lesson that, sometimes, what seems like insurmountable adversity through an adult’s eyes can, through a child’s simple acceptance and joie de vivre, enrich your life and give it deeper meaning.Following a cyber attack in Alaska, government officials have abandoned their computers and taken to using old-fashioned typewriters.Let joy be unconfined.I still have my original typewriter from my days as a junior reporter on the Solihull News and it was a loyal servant that never crashed, froze or ran out of battery. I may even request for it to be buried with me.It seems that my love for these machines is rivalled only by Tom Hanks (yes, that one) who has written a book of short stories about them and created an app called the Hanx Writer, which emulates the glorious click-clack sound as you type.Go on, try it. There’s no greater pleasure.No? Just me then...Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
