title: betfred actor undergoes incredible transformation
story: NewsBetfred actor undergoes incredible transformation after seeing himself as '20 years older flabby dad' in TV advertJohn May was tipping the scales at 16 stone and at the age of 31 he said he looked about 50 years oldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJonathan Humphries21:41, 11 AUG 2018NewsAt his heaviest John weighed 16 stone (Image: John May)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn actor has undergone an incredible transformation from a chubby dad-of-three into a ripped bodybuilder in just seven months after seeing himself on a TV advert. John May said the commercial was the turning point for him because although he was only 31, he thought he looked 50.  A selection of photos show the incredible change in his physique.  John, who also owns Sweeps barber shop in Walton, has appeared in several major advertising campaigns – but now is almost unrecognisable as he prepares to take part in his first bodybuilding competition. Now weighing around 11 stone, he is set to appear in the UK Bodybuilding Fitness Federation (BFF) North East Qualifier in Leeds next Sunday (August 19). At his heaviest, John was tipping the scales at 16 stone, and after the break-down of his relationship began feeling down and unhappy. But since January this year, John, from Liverpool, has transformed his life.  The 36-year-old first realised he needed to change around five years ago after seeing himself on a TV ad for Betfred bookies.  He told the Liverpool Echo : “I used to be into running marathons. Around 12 years ago I was running 50 miles a week, I loved it.   “But when I opened my barber shop my focus shifted and I was working all the time, I left the running to one side.  “Over time I started putting weight on. I went from 10 and a half stone to 16 stone. That was over five or six years.” John said time pressures at work meant he did not take proper breaks and would spend his shift eating sugary sweets. He said: “I would go to the shop and buy a big packet of Monster Munch, a chocolate bar and a bottle of coke. “Then I would be drinking Red Bull all day for energy and on the way home I could not be a**** cooking so I would probably stop at Pizza Hut or something.”  But after the Betfred commercial hit the airwaves, John began to realise things needed to change. He said: “It was that commercial. That was sort of the turning point for me. I was 31 and I looked about 50. “So I joined Slimming World and lost around two stone. But over the next few years my relationship with my baby's mum broke down and I was feeling a bit depressed.” John says there were further false starts, including training for a White Collar boxing event, as his weight yo-yoed up and down. His introduction to body-building came when a customer at Sweeps revealed he had “completely changed his life” through training.  John said: “He kind of inspired me. I wondered if I could do that. I asked him and he told me to go to Tierpro Gym in Waterloo.” John trained for a while before approaching the gym's owner and 2013 national body-building champio, Karl Tierney. He said: “I went to Karl and I said I want to do a show, do you reckon I could? He sort of looked at me and said 'anyone could do it, but you have got to work hard, forget everything you know, re-train your brain and the most important thing is consistency'.” John says with Karl's help he learned to treat food differently and said he began to think of losing weight as “getting out of debt.”

title: boy 10 who weighs 17
story: NewsBoy, 10, who weighs 17 STONE feels like a 'slave' to his weight and fears food addiction may kill himKyon Fritz Marriott's mum claims the NHS has let him down as he can't get the help she claims will save his lifeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByScarlet Howes22:00, 11 AUG 2018Updated22:27, 11 AUG 2018NewsKyon and his mother Nadine (Image: Stan Kujawa/Sunday Mirror)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy aged just 10 who weighs 17 stone fears he faces death if he cannot beat his food addiction. Terrified Kyon Fritz Marriott, who is believed to be Britain’s most obese primary school child, said he feels like a “slave” to his weight and his out-of-control eating. He is afraid to go outside and is in the grip of such helpless cravings he routinely binges in his family’s bathroom on crisps and chocolate he has stolen from the kitchen. In an anguished plea the lad, who stands 5ft 1in and has a 47in waist, says: “I just want to be a normal 10-year-old. I just want help.” But his desperate mother accuses the NHS of letting him down and says shrinking funding means he won’t get the help he needs to save his life.  Mum Nadine wants Year 5 pupil Kyon to attend the nation’s only residential weight-loss camp, MoreLife. But despite widespread concern over soaring childhood obesity, Government cuts mean not a single child has been referred to the &pound4,000 scheme on the NHS in over a year. Instead Kyon has been told to wait two years for surgery which will cost the NHS more than twice as much. Last night experts warned that the shocking case is a symptom of a “national health crisis”.  Nadine, 44, who claims Kyon has been taunted and tormented by other kids for years, said: “I am scared for my child. I am scared that if obesity doesn’t kill him, the bullies will. “I don’t understand why the NHS will fund expensive surgery but they won’t fund the psychological help he needs. Who knows what state he will be in by the time he is 12? “I live in fear that if his weight doesn’t destroy his health he will end up stabbed or beaten to death by the bullies who are making his life hell.” Kyon began piling on weight when he was only seven as a result of teasing at school. A vicious cycle of bullying and comfort eating followed.  He said: “People at school call me fat boy, burger boy or Homer Simpson. They kick and headbutt me. “I feel like a prisoner. I can’t go out and live a normal life.” Kyon’s plight comes after a report last month revealed that one in 25 British 10 and 11 year olds are grossly overweight. There are currently 2.5 million obese children in the UK. The treatment options offered to Kyon will raise serious questions over the way the health crisis is being dealt with by the authorities. Doctors say he will be offered a bariatric op, which costs the NHS up to &pound10,000, after he turns 12.  But childhood obesity expert Dr Rangan Chatterjee, GP and star of BBC1’s Doctor In The House, said bariatric surgery does not tackle the root cause of obesity in kids. He said: “Surgery is like putting a band-aid over the problem. It may get Kyon’s weight down but it’s not helping him in the long term. “Any therapy needs to take a 360-degree approach to the problem and people need to be dealt with compassion. This is the biggest crisis our country is facing.”  MoreLife founder Professor Paul Gately claims state-funded places for ordinary kids have been wiped out altogether as the NHS battles a &pound960million black hole. Paul, who has run the camp since 1999, said: “We have had kids all over Britain funded by local authorities and &shyClinical Commissioning Groups in the past. But we have had no kids through our doors in the last year who have been approved for NHS funding. “Around 80 a year once had their fees paid for, initially by NHS Primary Care Trusts and then, when they were scrapped, by CCGs and local &shyauthorities. But the money has run out.”  In 2014 Kyon went on an NHS nine-month dietary programme at a London clinic called the Mary Sheridan Centre and his weight stabilised. However four years later he was morbidly obese – 13st heavier than the average 10-year-old and too big for any school uniform. His mum admitted she feels guilty for serving portions of his favourite dinners too large for his age. She also conceded it is “really hard” to tell exactly how much food he consumes every day because he eats so much in secret. She told how he locks himself in the bathroom of their South London home for secret half-hour binges, hiding empty crisp packets and choc wrappers behind the sink and in his bathrobe pockets. Nadine, whose other son and daughter are normal weights, said: “When I first saw he had been stealing food, my heart broke. Now every time I hear the fridge door open I panic. “I constantly ask him what he’s doing. But I have to put my hands up as mum.”

title: dogs smuggled uk squalid conditions
story: NewsDogs smuggled into UK as 'designer puppies' in squalid conditions exposed in heartbreaking undercover footageEXCLUSIVE: The charity investigation found 1,200 designer puppies were found by border guards in just two years, but campaigners fear many more go undetectedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy SharpeScott Hesketh20:38, 11 AUG 2018Updated20:41, 11 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Almost 1,200 smuggled puppies have been seized at UK borders in just two years, the Sunday Mirror can reveal.  We uncovered the figure after an undercover charity probe publicised an appalling trade in designer dogs by &shyruthless foreign crooks. Vehicle-loads of tiny pups – many far younger than the ages on their paperwork – are transported here from Eastern Europe in heartbreaking states of distress. The trade is masterminded by &shycriminals cashing in on the craze for pedigree pets seen on telly reality shows and for owners desperate to show off their cute pooches on Instagram. Most of the dogs were found abandoned at ports in sweltering lorries, drugged to sneak them past checkpoints. Many were too young to legally enter the country and few were vaccinated against serious diseases like rabies and tapeworm.  Dogs Trust campaigner Paula Boyden says the legislation designed to protect animals is failing adding: “Illegally importing puppies needs to end now. We urge the Government to increase the penalties.” We obtained figures from the Government’s Animal and Plant Health Agency under freedom of information laws. The figures show that in the two years to January, 1,117 illegal puppies were intercepted in the UK. A complete breakdown of where all the pups were seized was not available but well over half were found at two major ports in Kent – 377 at Dover and 360 at the Channel Tunnel entry point in &shyFolkestone. It means on average almost two illegal puppies a day are being smuggled on to our shores. And the true total of dogs going through the trafficking pipeline is far higher, as many make it through - undetected or die somewhere along the horrendous journey. The evil trade is part of a Europe-wide organised crime racket netting bootleg breeders hundreds of thousands of pounds.  Gangs exploiting lax border controls are feeding demand for &shyfashionable breeds such as French and English bulldogs, pugs, chow chows and dachshunds. So-called “handbag dogs” which are so tiny they can be carried around can be bought in Eastern Europe for as little as &pound20 and sold for &pound1,200 here – so even small-scale operators can make &shythousands every week. Last year the canine welfare charity Dogs Trust spent six months probing one of the criminal networks. It discovered a web of crooked puppy farmers, vets and handlers in Lithuania and Poland were greedily exploiting the system. And it claimed four-week-old puppies with umbilical cords still attached had been subjected to a gruelling, 30-hour journey to the UK. Footage recorded by the charity’s investigators showed dogs kept in squalor, with poor hygiene standards and commonplace mistreatment of puppies and mothers alike. In the clips, the puppies are crammed into tiny cages which are then piled up and stuffed inside vans. One smuggler was recorded boasting how he nets 1000 euros, around &pound890, for each dog sold. Under UK Pet Passport &amp Import Regulations it is illegal to bring unvaccinated puppies under 12 weeks into the country. The rules do permit the importation of up to five dogs, provided they are at least 15 weeks old, microchipped and have proof of receiving rabies and tapeworm vaccinations.  However the footage shows that faking documents to dodge these rules is key to the smuggling operation. A handler in Poland is filmed boasting that dogs can be made to appear however old buyers want them to be. He adds: “If it’s two months, it can be made three. If it’s three, then four.” He holds up one puppy as a good prospect for smuggling because it has teeth, which would suggest it is older than it is. He says: “They took away five Yorkies from me at the English border because they were too young. “He looked into the papers, saw that it stated that the dog was four months old and it barely had teeth. In reality it was two months old.” Video taken in Lithuania shows a woman claiming to be a vet offering the investigator sedatives to silence the dogs. In subtitles translating what she is saying, she talks about waiting “for about half an hour or 40 minutes” and then advises: “When you are about to enter the checkpoints at the border inject the medication 10-15 minutes beforehand then wait a bit. It is a very strong sedative. The puppy will be able to hear everything but it won’t cry or make any noise. It will look like it’s sleeping.” She also offers the investigator medication to make the puppy “wake up” after clearing the checkpoint, urging: “Wrap it up and put somewhere it won’t be seen”. When asked about the risks of smuggling into the UK and if it happens often, she shrugs: “Everything happens.” The footage also appears to show a Lithuanian handler passing on falsified paperwork – and agreeing to supply the buyer with vaccinations to administer after arrival in Britain. A couple who adopted an English Bulldog found dumped in a bucket told how his traumatic start to life has left him with anxiety and behavioural issues. James and Charlotte Boult rehomed Snoop after he was smuggled into Dover from Hungary at 12 weeks old – three weeks below the minimum age required by law. Since his rescue, Snoop has had two surgeries to remove blinding ulcers from his eyes and received treatment from a behavioural therapist who believes his ordeal has given him severe anxiety. James and Charlotte already had a four-year-old bulldog called Buddy, who they bought from a reputable breeder. Then they decided to apply to adopt Snoop via the Dogs Trust Puppy Pilot scheme after watching a documentary about smuggling. James, a 32-year-old estate agent, said: “Puppy farming is crazy – really scary. Bulldogs are prone to health issues but more so when they’ve had poor breeding standards. These smugglers are exploiting Britain as a nation of dog lovers.” James and Charlotte, 33, of Milton Keynes, Bucks, soon found that Snoop had health problems which weren’t immediately obvious. James said: “He was tiny when he was found and we’ve got no idea what other trauma he might have suffered before we took him in. “He had two surgeries on his eyes in December and March, and vet bills aren’t cheap. “When he turned one he started to get a bit aggressive to Buddy, who is very social and chilled-out. “A behaviour specialist said a dog’s personality is formed in the first 61 days of life. When it starts to reach maturity those traits begin to come out. “But Snoop gets a lot of love and care and we are patient with him after his awful start. We hope he will learn to trust again in time.”

title: emmy wanted this pride britain
story: NewsPride of Britain winner Jake Coates says 'Emmy wanted this' after finding love six months after wife died of cancerEXCLUSIVE: In their first ever interview, Jake Coates and new girlfriend Jenna Elsby say the universe 'pulled' them together after a period of darkness in both of their livesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings19:37, 11 AUG 2018Updated23:23, 11 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPride of Britain winner Jake Coates stole the hearts of the nation by raising &pound142,000 for charity with wife Emmy as she was dying of cancer. But just over a year after her death, he has hit back at claims he found love again too quickly, insisting: “Emmy wanted me to meet someone.” The 33-year-old artist is now living with Jenna Elsby, also 33, and her four-year-old son Charlie. It is a romance that sparked a backlash from his late wife’s grieving family and followers of her inspirational blog. Emmy’s sister Sophie publicly slammed her brother-in-law for “disrespecting” her sister, who she claimed would be “heartbroken”. But in their first interview, the new couple tell how they felt they were destined to be together.  Jake said: “It’s tough when you get messages from people close to you saying negative things. “But people deal with grief in different ways and those messages were coming from a place of hurt. “I will never personally say anything against Emmy’s family but I did feel let down. I think if I had come out and said I had a girlfriend then, now or even a year from now, it would have been a hard pill for some people to swallow. “Emmy wanted me to be happy. She wanted me to meet someone, she told me that.” The primary school teacher died aged 31 in June 2017, less than a year after their wedding and just 18 months after being diagnosed with thyroid cancer.  In February Jake announced he had abandoned plans to have their baby using her frozen embryos and a surrogate mother after two failed attempts. Three months before that he had accepted an award for Fundraiser of the Year on behalf of Emmy at the Daily Mirror’s Pride of Britain awards. He continues to raise money for the Royal Marsden Hospital, London, by running marathons and it was shortly after the awards that Jenna – a marketing expert and lifestyle writer – got in touch to offer her help. They soon discovered plenty in common. Jenna grew up in Chepstow, south Wales, near Jake in Monmouth. And when Jake worked as a doctor at the Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney, Jenna lived just a short walk away with her Australian husband and young son.  “I knew of Jake through a mutual friend at school and I wanted to help so I got in touch and offered him my marketing services,” Jenna said. “I didn’t know much about his story because I’d been living abroad and then in my own merry hell going through a divorce with Charlie’s dad.” During Jenna’s separation from her husband, she lost a friend to suicide and a very close friend to cancer. “It’s something I lived through first hand,” Jenna says. “We were just in a really similar situation. “Bad stuff had happened and we were both a bit war beaten. “But we both have a really similar outlook on life which is it’s about the here and now and looking forward and creating happiness, whatever that means, every day.”  Jenna and Jake began messaging back and forth and arranged a business lunch in London just before Christmas. Jenna said: “We went into that business lunch with professional heads on but the conversations were informal from the get-go. Our pasts were linked. We came away feeling things maybe we shouldn’t have been feeling. “I felt like I’d known Jake my whole life. “Jake is not defined by his past in the same way I’m not defined by mine. There was an obvious connection between us and you have to open your heart to love again. In honour of those who can’t live a life, I know I have a responsibility to make every day count.” Jake said he felt an instant attraction to Jenna and for the first time he could see himself moving forward.  He said: “I absolutely had no intention of meeting anybody at that time. “It was the most unexpected thing. I was just trying to keep my head straight and focused and it was the last thing on my mind. “She walked out of Covent Garden Tube stop and she was all smiles. I fancied her a lot quite quickly. “I didn’t even know I was ready for another relationship until I met Jenna. No one was more surprised than me. “Jenna and Charlie played a huge part in helping me out of a dark place. They brought the sunshine back into my life again. “Towards the end of our first meeting – which ended up lasting about 10 hours – I actually leaned in for a kiss and she gave me a bit of a telling off.” Jenna added: “I liked him a lot. How can you not? He’s delicious. But in that moment I was shocked.”  The couple arranged a proper date and their relationship took off. In February, they jetted to Iceland on their first mini-break. And as Jenna beamed next to a suitcase on the train station platform, Jake snapped a picture, uploaded it to Instagram and made their relationship public. The caption read: “Who’s a lucky boy then?! Escaping again – this time for a few days of R&ampR and a little bit of marathon training to the end of the world with his gorgeous little ragamuffin!” Instantly, hurtful comments came flooding in, slamming Jake and calling Jenna “evil”, a “rebound”, “ugly” and “shameful”.

story: NewsEscort who earns up to £4,000 a week offering the 'full girlfriend experience' lifts lid on UK sex industryThe call girl, who works for one of Birmingham's largest escort agencies, charges £160 an hour and offers everything from sex to just spending a bit of time with a clientShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephanie Balloo16:26, 11 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An escort has revealed what life is like working in the sex industry in the UK's second biggest city.   The call girl, who works for one of Birmingham's largest escort agencies, earns thousands of pounds a week from her clients and offers everything from sex to just spending a bit of time with a client.   The woman, who asked to remain anonymous, charges &pound160 an hour and can earn anything from &pound3,000 to &pound4,000 in a single week, offering the 'full girlfriend experience'.   She told Birmingham Live that escorts are not pushed into the city's sex industry and said she enjoys her work, gaining thrills along with plenty of money.   She began escorting as a teenager when she became fed up of her job in retail. I was just curious, I wasn't pushed into it or anything - it was completely my choice, she said. I just wanted to try something new. But I ended up doing quite well so I quit my job in a shop and carried on doing it. She knew exactly what escorting was when she applied, having done extensive research into Birmingham's top three agencies, their reputation and prices. The manager met her for a drink and checked whether she had the 'right look' for the job before selling her to a client the very next day. When asked what drove her to lead such a controversial lifestyle, she said it is the thrill and the money. The escort, who describes herself as a white, blonde, barbie-looking thing also rubbished idea that escorts have sex with all their clients. Instead, she claimed only around 20 per cent of her customers demand intercourse with her. We could be going out for a meal, or just chilling at home - somebody has booked to take me to the Casino tonight, it can really vary. I remember my first job was a mature gentleman who paid for a basic service - we had wine and I stayed for an hour with him and kept him company. Luckily he was very nice and polite. It's not all having sex and stuff, it's more like company and chilling. Sometimes you're with people for a long time like ten hours, just chilling.  She added: Some of them do have wives, last night I saw a lot of people have arguments with their girlfriends, wives, they were in hotels and getting wrecked with escorts. But a lot of people know they don't have time for a wife, they're too busy making money. Property tycoons who own large apartment blocks make up some of her clients too, and around half of the men are single. Some have had wives in the past. I'd say it's about 50/50 of them being single or married and or with children. The escort - who is single due to work being tiring and time consuming - said some men have a stronger connection with her than others. One regular client even confesses his love for her and promises her everything should she ever wish to quit.  Her job often takes her to places like the four-star Hyatt Hotel in the city or the homes of millionaires, but she said this is not where escorts spend every night. Last night I was at the Travelodge for an hour. Sometimes you go to tower blocks, sometimes you go to people who live in house shares - it's not always really posh nice houses. That doesn't bother me, as long as they're nice and clean. I've got really nice regular clients who live in Handsworth in a house share. But equally, she has had clients who were rude, unclean and disrespectful - all of which leads to her refusing to give them their service. I've seen really horrible people that were millionaires who I wouldn't want to see again because they're not nice. If I don't want to do anything, or if they're not clean, they're p***** me off or they're rude, I will give them a limited service if I still feel safe. If they haven't showered properly and that's annoyed me, I will make them get in the shower and also give them a limited service.  But if they are rude to her, she leaves the premises and calls one of the agencies' drivers - who she says are there for their protection too. She said she was once chased around a hotel by a client she refused to have sex with as he had an STI. I refused to do anything with him, I was running around the hotel. Nobody is safe from any trouble, she added. Certain clients will even ask for 'special requests' if they have fetishes they want to fulfill. We do see some crazy people that want crazy things that are just a bit unconventional. And if that's something that's a bit out of my comfort zone or I don't want to do, but I feel like I don't just want to do that for &pound160 an hour, I can charge more. This can include taking graphic images of her, foot fetishes, purchasing her underwear or even asking to wear it themselves. I can charge an extra &pound3,000 for these things if I want, otherwise it's not worth my time as it's not what I want to do. She works four or five days a week and will always do one night shift within those hours. But her hours and pay varies, especially when business is booming and she can easily pick up extra hours. The World Cup was crazy, or maybe just one week I'll have clients who tip a lot, she said.

title: greyhound tests positive baldness cure
story: NewsGreyhound tested for drugs found positive for baldness 'cure' Regaine after shock win - landing trainer £1,500 fineTesters also found traces of diclofenac, used in Voltarol pain relief gel, in Dinnington Lady's system after the 7-1 outsider took just 45.41secs to hare round the 415-yard trackShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJohn SiddlePhil Cardy21:36, 11 AUG 2018Updated21:52, 11 AUG 2018NewsTrainer Derek Ogden (c) has been fined £1,500 after one of his greyhounds tested positive for RegaineGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA greyhound rated a 7-1 outsider won a race by such a huge margin it was tested for drugs – and proved positive for hair restorer Regaine. The &pound20 baldness cure boasts results “may become clinically visible in eight weeks” – but Dinnington Lady took only 45.41 seconds to hare round the 415-yard track. Shocked bookies queried the win and trainer Derek Ogden saw his beloved dog taken off for checks. Expert drug testers found minoxidil – the active ingredient of Regaine – and traces of diclofenac, used in Voltarol pain relief gel. Derek was fined &pound1,500 and severely reprimanded by the Greyhound Board of Great Britain which ruled he gave the drugs deliberately to enhance Dinnington Lady’s performance. But Derek claims the hair cure must have got there by cross-contamination after he used it to treat a bald patch on another of his dogs.  And – showing a bandage on his knee – he claimed the painkiller may have accidentally mixed in with the dogs’ mince when he fed them after applying the gel for his own pain relief. Fighting back tears, he insisted: “I never gave her anything. She’s a great dog – they stitched me up just because I’m good at training dogs. I used the Regaine on one of my other dogs, Champ, to get the hair back on his legs. “It may have been passed over to Lady because they share a basket and are always close to each other. “The other stuff – the Voltarol – I put on my knee for joint pain. “I mix their raw mince with my hands every morning and I must have done it after putting the cream on.”  Greyhound bosses have cracked down on doping since a report showed owners were using class A drugs cocaine and amphetamine as well as prescription drugs to make dogs quicker. The sport is big business with punters betting around &pound2.5billion a year on UK greyhound races. The Greyhound Board’s report on the race at Crayford, south east London, in February, said minoxidil “has a stimulating effect on the heart and can therefore affect a greyhound’s performance.”  It warned that the drug is known to have toxic effects on dogs. It said it “rejected Mr Ogden’s claim that the positive findings were due to inadvertent cross-contamination.” And it declared that “on the balance of probabilities, both substances were deliberately administered to influence performance.”  Even track boss Danny Rayment told investigators the dog “ran above expectation” despite it being her first race at a new stadium. Two months later Dinnington Lady won the Performance of the Month Award at Owlerton Stadium, Sheffield. Derek – who named the dog after his home village of Dinnington, Tyne and Wear, said he is so fed up he is quitting the sport. “I was really upset when they found me guilty and fined me,” he said. “It was a witch hunt. They didn’t accept anything. I’m not part of their clique. “There’s no way those things can make a dog run faster. It’s just daft. They’re not prescription drugs. “They fined me over &pound2,000 which I’m paying at &pound100 a month.

title: incredible mums who both toddler
story: NewsIncredible mums who both have toddler AND one-year-old quads form very unique friendshipCarla Crozier and Selina Torbett never thought they would find anyone who would understand exactly what their family life was like - until the Mirror brought them togetherShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola Small19:48, 11 AUG 2018Updated20:08, 11 AUG 2018NewsCarla Crozier and Selina Torbett lead VERY busy livesGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese two mums have really beaten the odds – finding someone to trade tips on raising a toddler and one-year-old quads. Carla Crozier and Selina Torbett both thought there would be no one to understand their daily struggle after each became pregnant by IVF – and got more than she bargained for. So when Selina spotted our story in the Sunday Mirror telling how Carla, 36, and builder husband Paul, 43, were expecting miracle quadruplets, she wasted no time in getting in touch. Carla already had daughter Darcie, now four, while Selina had three-year-old Myla. But after heartbreaking struggles to conceive, and long IVF journeys, both got pregnant again last year. And faced with the daunting prospect of raising four babies all at once, who better to turn to than someone going through the exact same experience?  Selina said: “When I saw your article about Carla, I’d just had a seven-week scan showing I was having quadruplets. “I was terrified and desperate to talk to someone else who had been in my position. “So I looked Carla up on Facebook and messaged her saying, ‘This might seem really weird, but I’m expecting quads too, can you help me?’.” And the bond the two women formed was instant. They started messaging each other every day – sharing tips and advice on coping with being &shypregnant with four babies. Selina, 28, added: “When I was worried about something, I’d send Carla a message and she’d &shyreassure me that was normal, it had been the same for her. “I don’t know what I would have done without her support.” Carla gave birth in March last year. At odds of 70 million-to-one, she had two pairs of twin girls – Isla, Demi, Alyse and Milla. Just four months later, Selina and her decorator partner Kev Ashe, 35, welcomed their four – identical triplets Roman, Arlo and Austin, and little Raeya, the only girl. With four babies and a toddler to look after, phoning each other became impossible for Carla and Selina.  But the two friends continued to message daily. Carla, from Grays, Essex, said: “There must be thousands of messages. “Messaging is easier because it’s impossible to find a time when we’re both free to talk. You rarely get a break. “I’ll be like, ‘They’re napping now, are you free?’ And Selina will say, ‘No, I’m just feeding them’. “And then later she’ll be free and I’ll be like, ‘No I’m feeding mine now’. “It’s been so nice to be able to have someone who actually understands what it’s like to have four babies. We haven’t known each other very long – but we have this really strong bond.” Selina, from Winchester, Hants, said: “I’ve been lucky because Carla has gone through everything first. I’ve been able to learn from her experiences. “In the beginning I wanted to know how she managed to feed all four babies at once. “Carla told me how she’d come up with the idea of rolling blankets to use as a bottle prop. “Then I was worried when mine weren’t sitting up at the right time, so I messaged Carla and she told me that it was fine, hers were the same. “We’ve been able to share tips on things like what high chairs and strollers to buy – although I normally come out best because Carla’s are a few months older, so she has gone before me.”  Carla added: “Yes, she can always make the better choice because I’m the one who has to trial everything out – her stroller is the better, lighter one, her van is the easier one to drive.” Selina, who recently returned to work as a nurse for one 15-hour shift a week, explained how vital the solidarity is. She said: “Because Carla’s the only one who truly understands what it’s like, I always turn to her when I want to vent. “In January I got asked to leave a cafe because they said my stroller was a fire hazard. “I was mortified. Everybody was looking at me and I felt like I’d done something wrong. “Other friends were like, ‘Well, why couldn’t you just leave the stroller outside?’ “But I messaged Carla and she understood. story: NewsMan goes for pint after work - and wakes up in MAJORCA (and his partner isn't too happy)Alun Griffiths, 27, from Merthyr Tydfil in Wales, says he received a phone call from his partner saying "food's ready" shortly after touching down on the Spanish islandShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChristie Bannon19:19, 11 AUG 2018Updated20:43, 11 AUG 2018NewsAlun Griffiths (left) and Nigel Lewis flew to Palma after going for a drink at a Welsh pub (Image: Alun Griffiths)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young British man has revealed how he went for a pint after work - only to awake in Majorca hours later with his pal.  Alun Griffiths, 27, says he received a phone call from his partner in the UK shortly after touching down on the Spanish island.  My Mrs rang me saying 'where are you?', said Alun, who got a taxi to Magaluf after landing in Palma with friend Nigel Lewis. He added: And I said 'I'm in Magaluf' and she said 'food's ready' and I said 'I'm not joking, I won't be home for a few days'. She wasn't best pleased.  Alun, from Merthyr Tydfil, Wales, had called in to the Gurnos Club on his way home from work on Tuesday, Wales Online reports.   He intended to simply have a few drinks with his friends - but he didn't end up getting home for another two days. He admitted he had woken up that day in a stupid mood. I was in work on Tuesday morning and I'd woken up in a stupid mood when you just get a feeling you're going to do something stupid, he said. After work I went to the Gurnos Club and there was about 15 of us all talking about holidays. So I said 'anyone want to go on holiday now? Let's go up the airport and see where we can go anywhere in the world'. Alun travelled to Cardiff Airport with Nigel, where they were told that they could book on to a flight that evening going to Palma. During the journey, they fell asleep - only to wake up in the Spanish resort.  After touching down in the city, they shared a taxi with some men outside the airport to nearby Magaluf. There's a Palma in Italy too so we didn't know if we were going to the one in Spain or Italy, Alun added. We fell asleep on the plane and woke up in Spain - thank God. With no hotel and no return flight home booked, the pair headed straight out until the early hours of the morning. They then continued to drink - but booked a hotel for that night. The first night we stopped drinking at 5.30am, Alun said.

story: NewsMeghan Markle could be waiting to have a baby with husband Harry for VERY practical reasonThe prospect of the newlyweds becoming parents in the near future has left royal fans extremely excited - but the wait could go on for a bit longerShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans22:56, 11 AUG 2018Updated23:00, 11 AUG 2018NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are both clearly at ease with kids (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Since tying the knot three months ago, Meghan Markle and Prince Harry have dropped some big hints about wanting to start a family.  Both clearly at ease with kids, the prospect of the newlyweds becoming parents in the near future has left royal fans extremely excited. But the wait could go on for a bit longer - because Meghan, 37, might be delaying getting pregnant for a very practical reason. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are due to embark on their first royal tour together this Autumn, including some long-haul trips.  They will visit Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand - with the trip coinciding with the 2018 Invictus Games in Sydney in October. Although the NHS says most women are able to travel safely while pregnant, morning sickness is very common in early pregnancy. It is typically at its worst during the first 12 weeks - with some women, including the Duchess of Cambridge, suffering from a severe form. During this period, mums-to-be can also suffer from extreme tiredness. These potential symptoms could prove difficult for Meghan if she was in the early stages of pregnancy during the highly-anticipated tour.  The risk of having a miscarriage is also higher in the first three months of pregnancy, regardless of whether you're travelling or not. And long-distance travel (more than four hours) carries a small risk of blood clots, or deep vein thrombosis, the NHS warns on its website.  According to The Sun, royals who are pregnant are advised to keep travelling abroad to a minimum for safety reasons.  Sarah Reynolds, a consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist at the Bedford Hospital NHS Trust, says: Travel during pregnancy is a concern for many women.  But if your pregnancy has no complications then there's no reason why you can't travel safely, as long as you take the right precautions. The royal tour will likely be packed with engagements, meaning Meghan may have decided to delay starting a family until after it's over. Prince William and wife Kate are also said to have waited to have a baby.  The couple were the first future monarchs in a staggering 200 years not to conceive in their first year of marriage, the  reports.  They did not announce they were expecting Prince George until 19 months after they tied the knot at Westminster Abbey in April 2011.  Royal author Gill Knappett said: “It is thought that William and Catherine, as newlyweds, may have delayed staring a family so that they could participate fully in the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee celebrations in 2012. “Part of William and Catherine’s commitment to the Queen in her Diamond Jubilee year involved the young couple touring Asia on behalf of Her Majesty in September 2012.” If Meghan and Harry, 33, do decide to start a family at some point in the future, there are some royal rules and protocol they'll have to follow.

title: mum 24 who inhaled up
story: NewsMum, 24, is left paralysed from the chest down after inhaling up to 15 'hippy crack' balloons every weekendOlivia Golding, 24, contracted a disease from nitrous oxide after bingeing on the balloons every weekend while her three-year-old son was at his dad's houseShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross10:53, 11 AUG 2018Updated15:42, 11 AUG 2018NewsOlivia would consume 15 balloons every weekend (Image: Olivia Golding/Facebook)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has revealed how she has been left paralysed from the chest down from inhaling too much 'hippy crack'. Olivia Golding, 24, would reportedly consume up to 15 balloons every weekend while her three-year-old son Parker visited his dad. She says the nitrous oxide (NOS) inside has left her with no feeling in most of her body after she contracted a Lichtheim's disease, also known as subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. She is having to relearn how to walk and use her hands. Olivia first became aware of the problem last Friday, when she woke up unable to move and had to ask Parker to get her phone so she could call her help.  The car saleswoman from Bristol, told the Mail Online : About a month before I was doing a balloon and I got pins and needles in my neck and back. I started feeling numb in my body. But I never dreamt it was the balloons so I just carried on doing them. One day I was walking in the park with my son and taking him swimming, the next day I couldn't move. She was admitted to Bristol's Southmead Hospital, where tests revealed the top of her spinal cord was damaged. They asked me if I took NOS and I was like, 'Sure, I've done a lot of them', she said. Olivia added: I cannot even put Parker's shoes on for him and it's the things like that [which] break my heart. My son wants me to play with him and I can't do that. I can't feel my legs, my whole body is twitching. Olivia has been using her recovery period to warn others about the dangers of NOS. Writing on Facebook, she said: I wanted to write this on social media to make awareness to all of my friends that also use balloons of what the balloon is actually doing to your body. If this just stops one person from doing them, I feel I would have succeeded in some way. I think we have all become almost expectant to the fact of seeing balloons being sold at festivals, on the streets and even in night clubs. Over the past month my body has slowly been becoming numb, deteriorating in front of me, getting to the point last week that I no longer could move my hands or even dress myself.  The nitrous oxide that is put into the balloon that we all crave for is actually starving your brain of oxygen and eating away at your nervous system - after having brain scans and MRI along with fluid taken from my spine I’ve now been diagnosed with my nervous system as damaged, I have no feeling in my body from my calves to my shoulders and cannot use my hands. The doctors are now going to focus on trying to reverse this but I wanted to make everyone aware that the 20 second high off that one balloon could cause you weeks in hospital teaching yourself to walk properly again. Please think of the consequences and raise awareness of nitrous oxide. In another post, she described how she is unable to move without assistance and is having to use a wheelchair to get around the hospital. My treatment has begun so now it’s a waiting game of the reversibility and the praying that it’s reversible, she added. The doctors have asked me to get the message out there about nitrous oxide and what they are doing to peoples bodies. I understand most people will look at this post and think ‘it won’t happen to me’ but I thought that when I was sat with my friends and going to festivals until I woke up last week unable to move. It’s really not worth it, so anyone, especially my friends, I’m begging you to stop as you do not want the feeling (or no feeling shall I say) of what me and my family are going through. Lichtheim's disease is thought to start when nitrous oxide starves the body of the vitamin B12 by stopping it being properly absorbed. The lack of vitamin B12 damages the fatty sheath protecting nerve fibres in the spinal cord which control movement and sensation. The condition is treated with vitamin B12 injections – which Olivia is receiving – and most people recover completely if this happens within a few weeks of symptoms starting. However, if treatment is delayed they may not recover from the movement problems caused by the irreversible damage to their nervous system. After a week in hospital, Olivia has managed to take 12 steps with help of physiotherapists. She is expected to spend a significant time in hospital with long term rehabilitation. It is illegal to supply or import NOS for human consumption, but the small silver canisters are still available in shops as they are legally used for whipping cream and as an anaesthetic.

title: mum says breastfeeding vs bottle
story: NewsMum says breastfeeding vs bottle debate is pointless as 'they all grow up to eat Haribo and McDonald's anyway'Beauty blogger Caroline Hirons, 49, from London, weighed in on the issue during World Breastfeeding WeekShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEmma Gill17:33, 11 AUG 2018Updated17:40, 11 AUG 2018NewsCaroline Hirons was supported by some mums over the pressure to breastfeed (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum's rant about whether to breastfeed or use a bottle has caused a storm online after she claimed it was a pointless debate because children grow up and eat junk food anyway. Caroline Hirons 49, from London, weighed into the discussion during World Breastfeeding Week about whether breastfeeding is best for children or mums could just use formula, the Manchester Evening News reported. The beauty blogger raged on Twitter : I can’t believe it’s 2018 and we’re still discussing breast vs formula like it matters at the end of the day. Just feed your kid and get on with your day. They all grow up to eat Haribo and McDonalds anyway. Yes, even your kid, kale-blending Cynthia in the pilates pants.  Her tweet provoked a torrent of messages on social media from other mums and has been liked more than 27,000 times. Although many supported her view, others branded the blogger clueless for ignoring mums with babies in poorer countries. Nadia Cruickshank complained: Clueless statement by a privileged person living in a rich country. WBW is not about you. What about the mothers living in countries with no access to clean water &amp cant sterilise bottles? What about the mothers who cant afford formula? Breast the safest for their babies &amp FREE.   She added: You completely miss the message of ‘World Breastfeeding Week’. I suggest you check out the website and educate yourself. Formula is a privilege. But Ms Hirons defended her tweet, writing: I’m hardly ‘clueless’ about BF thanks. I’ve done it four times. And I’m clearly talking about women in the westernised world being made to feel guilty by forums because they are struggling with it. Nestle pushing formula into poorer countries is another matter altogether.   Caroline Basden also lashed out, writing: I can't believe it's 2018 and we're still judging other mums like this - mocking people's food tastes, clothing and names. Facts: There is a proven benefit to breastfeeding. It doesn't always work out. Those who want it should be enabled to seek support.   And @subo118 said: How disappointing. The benefits of breast milk for both mother and baby are too great to trivialise and dismiss like this. There are other ways to be supportive and inclusive. But other mums backed up Ms Hirons, saying pressure was poured on mums by society to breastfeed even when they couldn't do so. Twitter user @mrsmcgibble said: Yes this!! When I had my son 2010 I tried to breastfeed. I tried and tried and tried.   We just couldn't do it. I made the decision to change to formula. That level of guilt was unreal, then for my midwife to turn to me and say by giving up you are failing your son. Broke me. And @LoubyLou49 said she'd done both with her twins - and could not see any difference in their health or development. She said: I had twins. One could breastfeed the other couldn’t. They’ve both grown up and are wonderful and utterly annoying in equal measure.  Mums told the Manchester Evening News how Ms Hirons' words had really resonated. Chantelle Kendrick, from Hyde, mum to three-year-old Max, said: The pressure to breastfeed was a contributing factor to my post natal depression, I spent 10 days struggling before giving up and felt like a huge failure. Even though my son's friends were all fed differently and I can see no difference in the kids, I still feel less of a person because I bottle fed. All the debate talk just resurfaces all those feelings and there’s too much emphasis on mums who breastfeed being 'super' mums - they seem to get a bigger pat on the back than bottle mums from my experience. It shouldn’t matter but there is a divide.  And Leanne Kirk, also from Hyde, added: Definitely boring now. Like you say some mums aren’t able to breast feed because of one reason or another so why make them feel bad?! Plus surely formula can’t be that bad for babies as they wouldn’t make it if it was! Do whatever is best for you. I tried at the beginning with my daughter and did it for about five weeks, it was horrific if I’m honest! Purely because she wasn’t getting enough and that was stressing her and me out so I stopped. I’m going to try again when my baby is born but if it doesn’t work then I’m not going to stress myself out about it. If it works, then great.

story: NewsPrincess Diana's sister dated Prince Charles before she did - and it didn't end wellPrincess Diana's sister Lady Sarah was one of the women Prince Charles was seeing before he finally settled downShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor13:42, 11 AUG 2018Updated16:05, 11 AUG 2018NewsPrincess Diana with her sister Lady Sarah (Image: Tim Graham Photo Library)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter Prince Charles met Camilla Shand in the early 70s, their love blossomed and they began dating. It wasn't easy, and it's believed he dated more than 20 women before he finally found Diana Spencer. There were a host of interesting characters along the way, including Diana's older sister Lady Sarah Spencer.  Not much is known about their brief relationship in 1977, but it's understood it all ended after she did an interview with the Mirror's James Whittaker . Recalling the event in 2011, James wrote: My mission improbable as a young journalist was to discover who Charles would marry and be first with the news. So when Sarah introduced me to Diana I should have taken more notice of the shy, gangly-16-year old. Sarah by contrast was a lively, lovely redhead and I was captivated.  Putting obvious obstacles aside – like she was totally out of my league and stepping out with the most eligible bachelor in the land – I chanced my arm. James suggested the pair meet for lunch when they got back to London, and she accepted. He said: Unfortunately another reporter overheard our exchange and also invited himself along, which added gooseberry to the menu. Sarah was disarmingly frank about her boyfriend and declared she would not marry Charles if he were the dustman or the King of England.  That was good news from where I was sitting and Sarah seemed delighted I was so keen to share it with the nation. But when Charles found out, he wasn't happy. He reportedly told said to Sarah: You have just done something incredibly stupid.  Despite the slightly awkward history, Sarah was said to completely approve of Charles and Diana's relationship. According to the , she said: I introduced them, I'm cupid.

story: NewsSchoolgirl Abi Longfellow finally gets new kidney after three-year campaign to give her the gift of lifeAbi Longfellow has thanked Sunday People readers - “I’ll never forget how precious this gift is”Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGrace Macaskill 22:39, 11 AUG 2018NewsAbi Longfellow (Image: Collect Unknown)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYoung Abi Longfellow has finally had a vital kidney transplant after a three-year Sunday People &shycampaign to help give her the gift of life. The schoolgirl today thanks our loyal readers for saving her when all hope seemed gone. Abi, 15, would have died if you had not got behind the fight to secure her the life-saving wonder drug being denied her by the NHS. Without the miracle medicine Abi’s one-in-a-million kidney &shydisease would have made her body reject a donor organ and she was not expected to reach her 18th birthday. But remarkably she is now &shyrecovering well after surgery at Leeds General Infirmary. From her hospital bed, Abi last night said: “I’ll never forget how precious this gift is.”  Abi got the call a donor match had been found when she was watching the British Transplant Games in Birmingham last week. Her family raced to Leeds General Infirmary where surgeons were waiting to perform life-saving surgery. Abi said: “I couldn’t believe it when we got the call after all this time. I was apprehensive but also relieved as I had waited so long. “I’m now watching Disney films and even managed to eat macaroni cheese and chocolate. “I want to say a big thank you to every single Sunday People reader who has supported me and my &shyfamily over the past three years. “There are also over 500 &shyincredible people who stepped forward willing to donate their kidney even though they have never met me. Thank you. Every single person gave me hope.  “I’m now looking forward to having a normal life.” Abi added: “To have received the call at the transplant games was really special. “I was surrounded by so many who have also been transplanted, but also living donors and those who so kindly donated their loved ones’ organs to allow others to live. “I’m so very grateful.” We first took up Abi’s case in May 2015 when her mum Jo and dad Andy, of Wakefield, West Yorks, were told a drug she needed was too expensive to &shyprovide on the NHS. Her extremely rare condition DDD – dense &shydeposit disease – was not common enough to be covered by NHS England’s drug-funding policy. But it was also not unusual enough to unlock cash set aside for exceptional cases. Without the &pound137,000 a year treatment there was a high chance a transplant would fail because the auto-immune disease would attack her kidneys.  Sunday People readers were so moved by Abi’s plight that a staggering 200,000 petitioned the Government. X Factor supremo Simon Cowell and Queen guitarist Brian May threw their weight &shybehind the campaign. And public law &shyspecialist Yogi Amin, of Irwin Mitchell, prepared a High Court legal action after offering his services for free. Finally the NHS relented and agreed to fund the drug. The victory means that other &shychildren in the same predicament as Abi will also now be given the &pound137,000-a-year medicine. But then Abi had to find a donor. Her mother Jo, 47, was discovered to be a perfect match but could not &shyundergo surgery because of a &shymedical problem. Her father Andy, 49, was heartbroken after doctors said he wasn’t suitable for surgery either. title: scope charity used chugging firm
story: NewsScope charity used 'chugging' firm run by millionaire who was fined £315k for breaking data protection rulesEXCLUSIVE: The national disability charity used staff from LPS Promotions to stop people in the street and get them to sign up for direct debit charity donationsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephen Hayward19:50, 11 AUG 2018Updated19:59, 11 AUG 2018NewsScope used a charity mugging, or 'chugging', firm to bring in donations (Image: www.alamy)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Britain’s biggest charities hired a “chugging” firm run by a millionaire who was fined for breaking data protection rules. Scope used “charity mugging” staff from LPS Promotions – run by businessman Roy Haydon – to stop people in the street and get them to sign up for direct debit charity donations. But Haydon also ran Elkador Finance which was fined &pound315,000 for failing to prove people’s data was collected legally. Elkador went bust in March with &pound330,271 debts and the fine – reduced to &pound143,640 on appeal – is still unpaid. The two companies even share the same address. Last night the Charity Commission said it would investigate our discovery.  The deal was uncovered after a Sunday Mirror reader was stopped in the street by two chuggers for Scope. He checked their ID and discovered they actually worked for LPS. The source said: “I am a supporter of most charities. But I like to check that they’re real fundraisers. I was horrified and felt annoyed that they had tried to coerce me into giving money to them.  “I understand charities need to raise money. But it’s concerning to see that people like this can work in the charity sector speaking to the elderly and potentially vulnerable people. “I will not be donating to Scope while they are using marketing companies such as this to generate income.” Disability charity Scope’s latest accounts show it took almost &pound16million in donations overall. Chief executive Mark Atkinson is paid &pound129,000 a year – just &pound21,000 less than the Prime Minister. Scope spokesman Philip Talbot said a fundraising firm it used had sub-contracted work to LPS without permission.  He said: “Like many other charities we use agencies to raise vital funds. “One of the organisations we use is Ultimate Marketing Services. We are bitterly disappointed that without our knowledge UMS hired LPS to fundraise on our behalf for just three weeks in July. “UMS should have obtained prior written permission from us to use any other agency. “LPS are no longer raising funds for Scope and will not do so in the future.

title: supermarkets branded bonkers shoppers deliveries
story: NewsPlastic waste: Supermarkets branded "bonkers" by shoppers as deliveries arrive in "unnecessary" packagingSome customers say they're still receiving items wrapped in packaging despite ticking the 'no plastic' optionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBryony Firth-BernardStephen Hayward19:54, 11 AUG 2018Updated20:04, 11 AUG 2018NewsShoppers are fed up with supermarket deliveries arriving in plastic bagsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShoppers are &shydrowning in “pointless” plastic as &shysupermarkets use more and more bags for deliveries. High street giants, who promised to cut packaging, have been shamed online by angry customers, while campaigners said the behaviour was “bonkers”. Shoppers say they are fed up of items turning up wrapped in plastic despite ticking the “no plastic bags” option. In many cases, the carriers contain just one item, such as a bag of crisps or carton of milk. Some are even placed in their own smaller bags so they don’t contaminate other food. The use of &shythrowaway plastic by our biggest &shysupermarkets has fallen by 86 per cent since the 5p carrier charge was &shyintroduced in 2015.  But the growth of online shopping has accounted for an increase in smaller, single-use bags. An Asda customer, who posted a picture of empty plastic wrappers online, said: “Great service. But could you please stop giving me so much plastic? I pick loose fruit and veg on purpose to avoid too much plastic. “Could I just opt out of plastic bags?” One wrote on Twitter: “Tesco please, please stop sending our online shop out in plastic bags. I select the no bag option and get a load of these instead.”  Sainsbury’s customer Maeve Wallace also criticised the “unnecessary” &shypackaging, saying: “I chose loose fruit and veg for a reason. And double plastic on chicken? Can’t see how it’s justifiable.” Waitrose shopper Darren Lewitt added: “I can’t fathom why Waitrose doesn’t use reusable crate liners for home deliveries? It’s hygienic as the food doesn’t touch the dirty crates.”

title: dad who let baby starve
story: NewsDad who 'let baby starve to death' claims he's being treated 'unfairly' because of his Christian beliefsSeth Welch and wife Tatiana Fusari, both 27, have been charged with murder and child abuse after their 10-month-old baby Mary was found dead in her crib in Solon Township, MichiganShare&nbspByPippa Allen-Kinross16:14, 11 AUG 2018Updated16:21, 11 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father who has been charged with murder and child abuse after his baby starved to death claims he is being treated unfairly because of his strong Christian faith. Seth Welch and his wife Tatiana Fusari, both 27, were both charged on Monday after their 10-month-old daughter Mary was found dead in her crib in Solon Township, Michigan, last week. An autopsy found she died of malnutrition and dehydration - and the couple are accused of failing to seek medical help despite knowing their baby was sick. But Welch maintains his innocence, insisting that there were no signs to suggest how unwell Mary was - and that she was a skinny girl.  In an interview from prison with news channel Wood-TV, Welch repeated claims that he cared for his children without the help of doctors because of his religious beliefs and said he was being persecuted for his faith. I believe I am being unfairly charged, being made an example of for my very strong faith, he said. Going to the doctor's office these days is just about as dangerous as not going. Welch also maintained his innocence, insisting that there were no signs to suggest how unwell Mary was and that she was a skinny girl. He said: This was a tragedy. This was not a crime. There was no ill will involved. There was truly no neglect involved. In the Bible, it says that good food is our medicine. We fed her. We were feeding her chicken, potatoes, apples, cheese. We were giving her the good stuff. She died. It's a tragedy… The Lord giveth, the Lord taketh. We did the best we could for Mary according to our faith.  Welch added: I don't fear the judgement of man because God knows how much I love that child. God knows the moments we shared together. An affidavit signed ahead of their court appearance last week said both parents had admitted they were aware of Mary Welch's skinny appearance and low weight for at least one month before she died. It added: Tatiana Fusari admitted during the interview that they failed to reach out for medical help with their daughter for fear of having her children removed by Child Protective Services, lack of faith and trust in the medical services and religious reasons. Welch insisted that Mary was found with a dirty nappy, showing clearly that she had received nourishment. Family court documents obtained by 24 Hour News 8 say there were dirty nappies in the bin in Mary's room, and that her mattress was wet and soiled and had a rip in it. According to the documents, Fusari returned home from work to discover her baby had died at around 10a.m on August 2. She said the last time her daughter had eaten was 2.30pm the previous day. Welch had been tending to Mary while his wife was away, and told investigators that Mary had gone to sleep at 2.30pm on August 1 and did not wake up. He said he checked on her by looking through a hole in the door but didn't go into her room because he didn't want to wake her. The documents say that after Fusari discovered Mary was dead, Welch waited an hour before calling police.

title: dundee boss mccann says nothing is happening with lawrence as jones set to sign instead
story: Neil McCann insists there is “nothing happening” in relation to a deal bringing Lawrence Shankland to Dens Park.Instead, the Dundee gaffer is set to add Shrewsbury striker Sam Jones to his attack.Speaking yesterday, Neil said: “Sam Jones is one we have looked at, one of a few but I don’t want to be disrespectful to Shrewsbury by commenting too much on it.“We have looked at him. We have asked the question and spoken to the club and I believe there is an agreement there but there is nothing agreed with him yet.”Ayr striker Shankland, who has started the season in scintillating form with nine goals in five games, has been linked with a move to Dundee in recent weeks.It was reported on Thursday that the newly-promoted Championship club had rejected a bid from an English side for their striker, but McCann, who has made it clear he is keen to add to his attacking options, played down his interest.“It’s really unfair to comment on any players I am after,” he said. “What I would say is that I have been in the market and been actively trying to get players.“Some have come close and fallen through, others not.“Lawrence is a very talented player.“I know him from my time at Dunfermline and have no doubt he could come to a club like Dundee and do very well, especially in the Premiership.“But as it stands there is nothing happening.”He added: “We tried to do some business on Thursday, it didn’t quite happen but we will continue working on that.”Dundee &#8216agree deal&#8217 for English attacker

title: dundee boss neil mccann delight at deacon return saying he could be massive
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is delighted to see “a player who could be really massive for us this year” has returned to training.Winger Roarie Deacon is yet to feature for the Dark Blues at all since the final day of last season after picking up an ankle injury in the 1-0 defeat to Partick Thistle.At the time, the injury didn’t seem too serious but eventually required surgery and has kept Deacon out of action for the entirety of pre-season and the beginning of the campaign.Last week, though, he posted photos on social media of his return to training and his boss was delighted to see the former Arsenal kid back in action.Neil said: “I was really delighted to see him back.“I was sick for Deacon because he got himself into great shape last year and he was so looking forward to hitting the ground running in pre- season but then he picked up a really innocuous injury against Partick.“He’s back running and I’m delighted with that because he’s a player that could be really massive for us this year.”Deacon remains a few weeks away from a return.When he does become available once more for selection, Neil admits he’ll have welcome decisions to make between his players.Something central midfielder Lewis Spence has given him thanks to his form of late.“We want to have decisions to make all over the place,” Neil added.“I thought Lewis’ display was brilliant last week. Maybe he just reinforced why I brought him to the club. Last year he was unfortunate with injury but I’m hoping he’s just one of many who tries to force his way into my starting XI.“If I get enough of those guys pushing then I’ve got a good headache to have this season.”

title: dundee boss neil mccann on leeds united target steven caulker i thought we would lose him
story: Neil McCann was left relieved after managing to hold on to a couple of key players as the English transfer window shut on Thursday afternoon.Glen Kamara and Steven Caulker were both linked with a move down south &#8211 with Leeds rumoured to be interested in the latter &#8211 but remain with Dundee, and McCann says there were never any offers despite the reported interest.“There have been no official bids put on the table yet for Steven,” he said. “Clearly he is a player that attracts a lot of interest.“The good thing is, I thought he would probably go and we would lose him, but we still have him.“We need to be thankful for the squad we have just now, because we could have lost a few players to down south.”

title: dundee sweat over fitness of star midfielder glen kamara for aberdeen clash
story: Dundee are sweating over the fitness of star midfielder Glen Kamara ahead of today’s visit of Aberdeen.The Finnish international went over his ankle three weeks ago and missed the Betfred Cup games against Peterhead and Brechin.He was expected to be fit for the Premiership opener at St Mirren last weekend but suffered a reaction to the injury on the eve of the game in Paisley.It’s unclear yet just how long that will keep the central midfielder out for but he is a big doubt for today’s home clash with the Dons.Despite falling to a 2-1 defeat to the Buddies, the Dark Blues midfield didn’t miss Kamara’s presence too much with Lewis Spence an able deputy with Kharl Madianga, Elton Ngwatala and Paul McGowan ahead of him also performing well.And those four are expected to continue today from the start.Meanwhile, the English transfer window shutting yesterday evening was good news for Dundee fans with Kamara and Steven Caulker still at the club.Kamara had been linked with a move to newly- promoted Premier League side Wolves and Championship Swansea.Loan moves are still available to Football League clubs but the Dark Blues would be unlikely to accept a loan-to-buy deal with the 22-year-old’s contract expiring at the end of the season.Both Celtic and Rangers had been credited with interest in the midfielder and they have till the end of the month to make a move if they so wish.Central defender Caulker had been linked with a £1.5 million move to Leeds United this week but that failed to materialise.Turkish side Trabzonspor have also been credited with interest in the England international.

title: dundee united boss csaba laszlo mulls changes as he seeks better show at queens
story: Dundee United boss Csaba Laszlo faces some key selection decisions as he tries to get his team back to winning ways at Queen of the South today.After an opening day league defeat that saw three goals conceded in the second half against Dunfermline last week, his desire to make changes is obvious.However, a number of factors, not least fitness, will come into play before he finalises his line-up.Stewart Murdoch could return to the defence if he’s recovered from the swollen knee that forced him to sit out the Pars clash and the recent Betfred Cup trip to Elgin.And if he’s come through training this week without any reaction to the knock that’s sidelined him since last month’s defeat at Ross County, full-back Callum Booth will also return to the squad.After almost a month out, though, it may be the best he can hope for is a place on the bench.And the fact today sees United’s first outing of the campaign on a synthetic surface could be a factor in whether or not the pair are involved.Whoever he decides, or is able to use, Csaba will be looking for much better this time round.While injuries have ruled out various key players in the games so far, he believes those taking their places should be doing so with the aim of hanging on to them even if everyone is fit.“I have said to the team you cannot wait for Fraser Fyvie or Stewart Murdoch or Callum Booth or Billy King,” he said.“You should not just be a shadow for these players, you have to deliver, make competition for places.“They want to play in the first XI when they are fit – do you want to just give them your place?”

story: The Scottish Government has recruited 93 people in Dundee to work at the country’s new social security headquarters.Competition was fierce, with 1,367 applications made within a few weeks of the client service advisers’ roles being advertised, according to official figures.The city’s jobs boost is the first wave of appointments for the agency, which is initially operating from the council’s base on North Lindsay Street.The advisers will be processing applications and responding to queries.The starting salary was advertised as £17,641.The agency is expected to be fully operational by 2021 with 1,900 jobs spread across the country, 750 of which will be in Dundee.It’s expected 80 posts will be filled in this recruitment round, but the number of people appointed is higher because of working practices such as job sharing.
